text: On tap at BitterCreek Alehouse clear redish brown with a fine dense tan head leaving smooth even sheets of lacing. Smooth malty woody slightly sweet flavors. Mild hop character. Very nice

On tap at Baileys, pours a hazy orange amber with a medium beige head. Aroma is quite hoppy for an alt, with notes of German lager yeast, bready malt and some dry hopping. Flavour is extremely hoppy for an alt, with piney dry hopping and bready malt. Quite astringent on the finish. Well-made avant garde alt beer.

Victorys 10 Year Alt, I believe, is much higher than 4.7% at 7.8%.This special anniversary lager has been offered again on tap at the brewery for their 20th birthday. The lacing is good, and the malts and mouthfeel are the backbone for this one. However, there is a nice, bitter finish. Cheers!
Draft at Churchkey. Clear ruby amber color, off white head with solid lacing and good retention. Aroma of burnt caramel and burnt toast. Taste is peppery burnt toffee very good example of the style.
On tap at hop city in Bham; Clear brown with little head; brown sugar aromas; syrupy but not cloying palate; hops in the finish; good beer.

4 oz pour on draft at ChurchKey during the Victory 20th anniversary event. Clear golden amber with off-white head. Aromas of citrus, malt, light floral notes, biscuit. Tastes of citrus, tropical fruit, floral notes, light biscuit. Medium-light body with a dry finish.
Some tobacco and some light roast. Some basement resin vibe. Light caramel. Amber pour with decent head. Light bittersweet finish. Tap at churchkey.

Beer Table To Go, NYC tap: well apparently this beer is back because I had it on tap at a reputable establishment. Pours clear brown with a beige head. Aroma is malty and hoppy... Some toffee and sugar and stuff. Taste is malty and not too sweet. Hops give themselves a nice presence. I like it when altbiers do things right. This is one of them.

A great strong brew, doesnt taste like your typical 8.5% brew.  Amber color, big foaming head that leave laces on the glass.  Nice spicy hop flavors as well as roasted malt character.  Well balanced.  One of my favorites from Victory.

I pop the cap and come back after writing an email and thier is 2 inch growth hanging from the bottle. There is huge carbonation that is chunky and heavy and puffy. When its poured into the glass the beer is very dark brillant amber color with a huge 5 finger light tan head that lasts several minutes. The peak of the head is awesome with big bublles and creaminess that makes you want to let your lips sleep on it. The lacing is great. As that huge head falls it coats the whole glass, like a film falling all the way to the body. 

The aroma is very malty, lots of sweetness and spice. 

The taste is almost very malty, reminds me of a lighter quad. There is light hops and a very nutmeg spice finish that lasts a little to long.

G: Poured into a Tom Collins glass. Bottle has an enjoy by date of May 7, 2009.

A: Reddish brown with a beautiful, crisp rust-colored head. Plenty of visible carbonation. Great lacing.

S: Sweet with some fruit notes. Very inviting. Caramel notes and some hops. Maybe some candied sugars.

T: Absolutely lovely. All of the aroma definitely comes through and there is a good amount of complexity to this one. Excellent malt backbone with some hops coming through. Similar to many of the darker American Strong Ales that Ive had. There are some slightly spicy notes in addition to the aforementioned aromas.

M: Medium-to-full body with a moderate amount of carbonation. Very nice. Some slight alcohol presence.

D: Could definitely drink this all day.

12oz bottle.Two caveats here: one, I generally dont like the altbier style; and two, the sample I tried was 5 years old, with a note on the label to "enjoy by Aug 07 06." 

very cloudy, chestnut brown. Flaky yeast owigng to age.nice head, decent amount of lace. Aroma is malty, nutty, crisp hop bitterness and notes of maple syrup. Flavor: rich malt, nutty, bready, crisp assertive hop blooms at the end of the swallow. Finish: full body, rich, long bitter, sugary. Best alt Ive ever had. I actually enjoyed it even though I usually hate the style, which has me wondering if it was done well outside of style guidelines. Other than yeast flaking, it survived its 5 years in my pantry quite admirably.

Bottle courtesy of EithCubes.  Pours a hazy, amber body with a moderate, beige head that is frothy and tight.  Caramel and toffee in the nose with some brown malt and light brown sugar.  Hints of pitted fruit.  Flavor has plum and raisin up front.  Some alcohol and astringency are also present.  Medium bodied with a good malt presence and nice, firm bitterness.  Astringent finish.  Overall decent but weird.  Not the clean, German character that I would expect.

Draft at Belgian. Pours a clean amber with a thin, creamy tan head. Aroma of chestnut, hazelnut, Burt, bitter malt, and wet dog. Medium bodied with a smooth, slightly bitter palate. Finishes with a coppery, metallic note. Average.

(My notes had this listed as "20 Year Alt", which is obviously wrong since it seems Victory started brewing in 1996.) Deep, reddish/caramel colored under a fairly thick ecru head which falls to a ring and leaves a nice lace spackle. Call me crazy, but the dominant aroma is that of grape Bubble-Yum. Tang. Cranberry. Minor dark fruit. Flavor is surprisingly hoppy to start (peppers), but a malty base does well to temper and balance. Dry caramel. Tea bitters. Old Ale leanings. Regardless of whether or not its "to style," its still a really nice beer.  ~~~~~~~~ Draught pint at Victory brewpub, several years ago (old notebook).

Bottle: Poured a deep hazy brown color alt with a large foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of deep caramel malt is very nice with some subtle toffee notes also noticeable. Taste is very refreshing with some rich caramel malt notes and some balance sweetness. Hops are very hard to distinguish which is a good thing since the malt bill is generous enough and need no complement. Full body with good carbonation and no apparent alcohol. Interesting take on the style and easily drinkable.

Murky amber-brown pour off white-tannish head .... creamy light lacing aroma of caramel, toffee and bready malts .... very malty taste caramel and toffee, roasted malts with a hop bitterness in the finish ... a nice brew the hops changed the style a little but didnt hurt it
Draft. Brown pour with white head. Weird malty aftertaste which put me off towards this beer. Mostly malt flavored, some hops possibly and spices are in the background. Not so good...

Bottle. Clear amber brown with a thin white head. Aromas of brown bread crusts, caramel, slightly spicy. Bready and toasty flavours with subtle spice. Nothing to blow you away, but delicious in the same way a simple homemade loaf of fresh bread can be.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Bottled. A hazy amber beer with a huge brown head. The aroma has notes of malt as well as lighter notes of spices. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and spices.

I received this bottle as an extra from leftmindedrighty, thanks! I think this must be about a year old at this point. I poured it into a standard pint glass (was I supposed to use a pilsener?). The color was a murky brown, not a color I usually see in my ales. The smell was faint (my sense of smell sucks) but malty. The taste was a little sweet but that did not affect drinkability. The alcohol was unnoticeable. I was expecting to get some sort of banana or clove taste but I didnt. I would definitely buy this if given the chance. Another victory for my taste!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-21-2007 15:44:09
Bottle.  Pours an amber body with an off whtie head.  Malty caramel,l bitter and herbal earth tones.  Dark roasted malt, with a strong bitterness to finish.  Decent beer, as for alt...
Cloudy amber with a medium off head. Aroma was sweet with plums, roasted malt and figs. Flavour had dark fruits, caramel and roasted malt. Somewhat oxydized and it had warning alcohol.
Very much like the description says, it starts out with a very assertive hop flavor and aroma and mellows out to a very grainy sweet maltiness.  This beer is big and tasty.
Received this in an extra on BA. This beer pours a little cloudy golden brown color. a little sweet , with a little hop present. Very nice beer. would love to have this all the time

Pours a very hazy yellow/brown with very little head. Aroma is quite dry, with a cereal malty base and very bright, fresh, grassy hop notes. Flavor is more subdued than the aroma, somewhat watery while a bit sweet and then following with the hops. Palate is also a bit watery, and the carbonation is a bit too harsh as well. A decent beer that is more interesting to smell than it is to drink.

12 fl oz bottle, courtesy of Ungstrup. Pours almost clear and golden orange with a a small off-white head. Aroma is dry malty and somewhat oxidised. Subdued sweet and slight hoppy flavoured. Caramel and slight spiced flavoured. Ends dry and malty.
Bottled. Slightly hazy amber coloured. Malty and bready aroma. Sweetish malty flavour. Medium bodied. Doesnt taste like 8,5%.

Bottle.  Pours red-brown with a nice creamy head and ample lacing.  Aroma of caramel and wintry spice.  Flavor starts earthy, but is quickly lightened with spice (nutmeg, clove) and soapy hops.  Palate stays creamy throughout, coating your mouth with goodness.  Finishes long, earthy, roasted and slightly bitter.  Excellent for an Alt.

Enjoyed via 12oz bottle.  The nose is one of strong maltiness.  Appearance is dark brown in color, with a light tan head.  Flavor is highly malty, almost similar to a doppelbock.  The finish is sweet, but not overly so.  A classic interpretation of a traditional style.
Moderate malt aroma with a little bit of hops. Clear orange color with a large tn head. Mild bitter beginning with a light sweet finish.

pours an brownish-orange color reminiscent of iced tea.  nice light tan thick head with great retention and lacing.  aroma had notes of caramel, citrus, wheat, and alcohol.  flavor is spicier than i anticpated with nice caramel backing.  mutfeel is silky and the finish is very dry and lingering with a warming effect.  I enjoyed this more than i expected.
Found a bottle of this and really enjoyed it. Poured a cloudy, dark amber color. A nice sweet malty aroma with a hint of hops. A full-bodied malty taste with a nice finish of spicy hops.

Very good beer.  Malty and with nice touches of caramel.  This is the type of beer that make a resurgence in our hop "shortage" present.  Makes for a good winter beer without the spices... should be a regular addition to an already diverse lineup.

Pours a dark amber/ chestnut brown color with a thin tan/ yellowish head.  Malty aroma with hints of hazelnut and subtle hops.  Nicely balanced with a strong malty flavor evening out the hops, chocolate and roasted nuts.  Much more complex than the usual suspects in this style.

I’ve had better brews from this company.  This one’s not too bad but nowhere near some of the other ones I’ve had.  Has a strong malt scent with subtle hints of hops (which seems to be Victory’s bread and butter).  Tastes mainly of malts. Has a strong malt aftertaste that isn’t too pleasant to me.  But it’s not a bad thing, I personally am not a malt flavor type of person.  I’m happy to have tried this one out.

Bottle. Moderate aromas all around with nutty and caramel for the malt, pine for the hops, earth for the yeast, and raisin, butter and brown sugar in the background. Head is frothy, light brown, with good lacing and is moslty diminishing. Color is hazy verging on murky caramel. Flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic, and the long finish is lightly acidic and heavily bitter. Palate is medium to full, creamy and has a lively carbonation. An excellent balance in flavors and aromas, this is the best Altbier I’ve had. No surprise from Victory.

This is what good beer is about. Bottles poured a nice creme head,  cloudy carmel red color.  Mild hoppy odor with sweet floral undertones.  Tasted medium body, creamy body.  Nice long after tastesweet and bitty.

Clear orange-brown pour with a fluffy white head and nice carbonation and lacing on the glass.  Sweet caramel and molasses aroma with some yeasty bread notes.  Very sweet and syrupy.  Malty flavor with caramel, molasses, and chocolate milk.  Intense bitter hops dominate the finish.  Bitterness lingers on the tongue for a while.  Hides the alcohol well.  Not bad, but too syrupy.

In short: An overtly syrupy sipper with good Altbier elements.  Almost good.
How: Tap at Firewaters, Atlantic City
The look: Clear amber body topped by a medium beige head
In long: Earthy caramelized hazelnuts, unexpected milk chocolate notes, red fruits of all kinds, annoying alcohol presence, way too sweet, a little sticky, strong hop bite.  I really enjoyed the earthy and nutty elements with the red fruits flavour but the sweetness and alcohol really took this beer down a few notches.  This is not a highly drinkable Alt, and Altbiers should be highly drinkable.  Heres to another ten years of hopefully better beer than this one.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of Summer Secret Santa.  Pours a hazy amber brown with a moderate off-white head that lasted through mid-glass and left very light lace.  Mild aroma of malt with just a few notes of hops as well.  The flavor is very malty up front. The malt is not sweet though, and lacks depth.  This is followed by some restrained hops that provide a dry finish and very little bitterness.  There is an odd copper flavor towards the finish as well.  Probably not something I would come back to.

bottle..dark amber pour,small white head.sweet caramel malt nose with a touch of fruit .very hoppy upfront followed by  woody ,sweet caramel malts and fruit flavors . bitter ,metallic finish . decent not great

Bottle. Caramel-sweet nose with some strawberry and raspberry fruit character. Clear pale red, thin head. Flavor opens sweet and estery, finished a bit harsh but with nice fruit esters. Gets more harsh as it warms.

Pours a dark amber color with an off white head. Aroma is very malty but with some hop undertones mixed in. Flavor is also very malty, but well balanced by the hops, nice dry crisp finish. The only complaint is a slight coppery taste. Nothing the stands out here but very drinkable, hides the alcohol well, and has a nice price.

Top notch stuff. Nice sweet malty aroma with a sweet malty taste but followed by a nice hop kick. Finish is crisp and dry. I would never have guessed the ABV as it is very well hidden however there is a nice glow after a couple
This is a very crisp,clean, drinkable beer.  Not assertively flavorful, but not boring either.  The alcohol is well hidden making this one very enjoyable.  Got more than I expected out of this one.
(Bottle).  Excellent offering.  Deep brownish red in color.  Thin beige head.   Well balanced flavor, accentuated by lively hops.  For the rest, the commercial description is right on target.
From a bottle poured a brown color with a good amount of head.  Nice toasted malt flavor with a lingering aftertaste.

Tasted somewhere along my trip through the States.
Amber colored brew. Sweet, malty aroma. Flavor is sweet, fruity and a bit hoppy. Pretty decent, but not very exciting.

Draught, Redbones dubbed Victory "Limited." Deep amber red with pretty lacing. Grain and fruit-forward nose, lots of pie crust. Very fruity. Rotten fruits, metals, perfumes, some rubbing alcohol and soap, unfortunately. Not my thing.

A deep copper color with a bit of an reddish hue.  The head was a light butterscotch color, about 2 fingers.  The aroma is mostly caramel, but also has some vanilla, apricot, and a bit of spiciness.  The flavor is very powerfully hopped up front.  Some oaky bourbon characteristics and a noticeable alcohol.  It has a pretty sweet toffee flavor and perhaps some cider, but the bitterness bookends those flavors.  Just a little bit out of balance in my opinion.  A full creamy body.  Very nice.
Maybe the best alt I have ever had.  Lightly metallic hops over lightly sweet malt.  Perfect balance, a treat to drink.

Bottle. Pours a root beer brown with a full tan head. Aroma of toasted malts. Good carbonation feel on the palate. Alcohol presence is immediately felt. Full bodied yet quite drinkable ( I had four). Finishes crisp and clean. Overall, beer is unique in style and very tasty.

Bottle.  Pours a deep dark amber/brown with a thick tan head.  Aroma of roasted and burnt malts.  Flavor of roasted lager malts (similar to a Doppelbock), apple juice, bread, soda-like quality.  Very malty, not much hops at all.  Full palate.  I liked it but it is quite burnt/malty in the doppelbock style, if that appeals to you.  Tasty beer!

Bottle. Aroma of rich, roasted, earthy, coffeeish malts. In the mouth it was a bit on the burnt side for me, but still pretty tastily earthy. Strong mouthfeel if you want that intense burnt malt character. Very good beer, if not my favorite style.

pours dark brown with a white head and plenty of lacing.aromas of caramel and spice. flavors are HEAVY caramel, brown sugar, and spice. lots of bitter hop backing. hints of baker’s chocolate and apricot. long, awesome bitter finish.

Tall on malt tall on hops short on head its copper just before the patina. It has a mild aroma the hops at light and there is asweet vegtable smell. The first tastes smashes the mildapparence of the nose. Vegitation sweet with hops and tons of malt. Its biter and stiff.
dark brown with a nice white head.  large malt aspect, possibly even some smoked malt in there?  nice hop bitterness.  the alcohol is rather prevalent.  a powerful and overall good beer

Pours a medium amber/brown with a medium off-white head.  Appearance is a nice color but a bit cloudy.  Taste is malty, with hints of caramel, licorice, and alcohol.  This is a full-bodied beer with a robust taste - very nice.

Bottle courtesy of hellbilly.  Pours a very dark, clear amber with one finger tan head.  Nose is malt, light nuts and honey.  Taste is caramel, hops and a burnt, smoky malts with a bitter aftertaste that lingers.  Medium mouth feel.  Decent beer.  Thanks Joshua!

THOUGHTS: Not really my cup of beer, but not bad. I had this back before I started rating beers and finally found it again. Not bad until the ear waxy-like finish. Hid alcohol fairly well. Tons of flavor and quite complex. My review doesn’t do it justice, because it’s not a style I’m familiar enough with.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a clear, medium to dark brownish red amber (like a darkened penny) with great carbonation and an average-sized, creamy, off-white head that left mostly diminished but left good to fair lacing. The aroma was grain, toasted and caramel malts, moderate herbal, resin and spicy hops and sort of a smokiness.
The initial flavor was moderate to heavily sweet and lightly acidic; while the finish was moderate to heavily sweet, heavily bitter, and sour with a long duration. There was caramel, smoke, roasted malt and then some resin hops. The medium body was syrupy then dry with fizzy carbonation and a light to moderate astringent and very metallic finish.

Just plain old beery aroma, nothing offensive and no hint of the hop flavorburst within. Looks like rootbeer in my sniffer. Probably one of the strongest alt beers I’ve ever tasted at 8.5%.  IMHO, taste is way too hoppy for an alt.  Almost comes across like an IPA!  IPA lovers better check this stuff out. Leaves a bitter lingering finish, like any other IPA, in your mouth. Way too many IPA characters for this pale lager lover. Generally, I really like alts but this stuff is over the top in hops.  For the style, cannot hold a candle to other alts like 	Schell Schmaltzs Alt, Erie Brewing Heritage Alt, Southampton Secret Ale, Penn Alt er Ego or even John Harvard’s Alt Bier.  Finish is hop mouth coating soapy chewing on grapefruit rinds terrible lingering bitter. Go figure, should be styled as an IPA. Probably on par with Otter Creek Copper Ale.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Orangey head.  Large Munich malt aroma full of biscuits and breadcrust.  Richly caramelly, sweet Munich overdose.  A shade husky/minerally.  Decent, but perhaps too assertive for my taste.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of Naka.  Pours a lovely copper with rich, red hues and a one finger, slightly khaki head.  Nose is sweet caramel malt with floral hops, mild fruit, and some earthy notes.  Taste is caramel with mild chocolate sweetness and lots of earthy bitter.  Some floral and pine hop notes with some citric character.  The bitter vanishes at the end but appears again, mildly in the after.  Decently dry finish with some sticky hop notes.  Pretty decent alt.

pours from the bottle a rich coppery brown with a thin off white head. sweet cereal grain aroma with notes of fruit/cherry?, grass, dirty/earthy mildly bitter hops and a smidge of umami. grainy moderately sweet flavors include caramel, grass and citrusy hops. dry finish parches the mouth a bit. medium body and a little sticky.

Draught @ Lower Depths Boston 08.

Red pour with big puffy head.  Sweet scent with a lilting malt wafting off it.  Flavor is well balanced malts and bittering hops with a burnt undercurrent.  Carb was well placed at a low level.  Nice

Ruby red with a largish off-white head.  Aroma is sweet with caramel , and a little beety.  Taste is same, and nicely roasted with an acrid twinge at the end.  Much better than I remember it when it was first released at Victory. $2.5/12oz

A decent altbier. Aroma was nice. Very hoppy for the style with some earthiness and roasted malt. Pour was very nice. A medium dark gold (a little light for the style)  with a nice 2 finger tan head. Taste was good. Roasted and burnt caramel with a nice bitter hoppy aftertaste. Citrus hops grip the cheeks after the swallow. Not much carbonation to liven the beer up. Good beer.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Pours a four finger cream head that fades slowly and leaves a good lace. Clear amber/mahogany color. Good carbonation and medium bodied. Malty/hoppy nose. Flavor is caramel with the hops balancing.  Unusual Alt. Very smooth with a very late hop bitterness. $2.00 for a 12oz bottle from Yankee Spirits South Attleboro, Ma.

Pours a beautiful  dark copper with a perfect, thick tan head. Heavy malt aroma, caramel, and maybe some yeast. Malty start is good, lots of caramel and light cherries, but it clashes with the hops and the finish is a little sharp before it settles out. Body is smooth before that spike, and the finish leaves an okay floral, bitter sweetness.

Very unique brew; pours clear brown with tannish full head; smells of sweet alcohol and bittering hops; tastes smooth and luscious; big malt backbone well balanced and easy; Euro bittering hops kick in at the end for nice finish; very nice unique brew from Victory.

On tap at the Frisco grille in Columbia, Maryland.  What a great showcase for malt in a beer.  I have never had anything that tasted quite like this.  Aroma was a bit on the sweet side with just a hint of hops.  Poured a beautiful ruby color with a thick white head.  The malt flavor was certainly unique and very tasty.  Surprising beer, but very good.

Bottle.  Deep amber with a very thick, sticky white head.  It is practically jumping out of the glass.  Nice herbal/spicy hop aroma over a very soft bready pale malt base.  Softly toasty and caramelly with loads of sweet maltiness.  There is a nice light bit of earthiness.  Warming brings up some light fruitiness as well on top of the noble hoppiness.  The beer is quite nice, but the hops seems a little bit faded in this particular bottle.

Pours clear brown/amber with a thick tan head. Nice creamy, malty aroma but a little weak. Flavor starts with caramel malt and hops then finishes with some alcohol and an unpleasant herbal/hop note.  Not a favorite from Victory but still interesting.

bottle.  Dark ruddy amber color, with a smallish off-white head that leaves a thin layer of foam.  Mellow aromas consisting mostly of light floral spices and dark bread.  Flavors start with an even floral bitterness and move on to smooth, dry toasted grains with a little bit of a yeasty twang.  Superbly balanced flavor on all fronts.  Very even and balanced on the palate, with a crisp smooth finish.  Great brew.
12 oz bottle. Pours clear red body with no head. The aroma is strawberry. The taste is slight hops, but lots of alcohol. PASS ME A GOLDEN MONKEY INSTEAD
Pour was a red color, no haze, high carbination.levels.  Aroma of hops and strawberry.  The flavor was of hops and alc.  It was not very smooth and really weak palate.
From a bottle pours a dark red/copper color.  Aromas of roasty malts, coffee, and some hops.  big malt taste with some hops in the back.  Creamy body. good brew from Victory.

Pours to a deep caramel color with a quickly dissapaiting head.  The aroma is faint, sweet and yeast like.  The taste is very good, well balanced between hops and malt.  The finish is bitte, with a very nice dose of hops.  Another solid brew from victory.

I did not realize this was getting released again. Wahoo!! This beer is beautiful. Deep reddish brown hues with a strong, thick, creamy beige head that leaves nice lacing. Smells a bit weird, with some sulfur and sewage notes, but mostly its a hop bomb in the nose with citric, piney and floral notes. Some sweet caramel and chocolate undertones hide in there as well. Super smooth and creamy taste. Very complex and hoppy, but enough subtle malts to balance it all out. A little bit of cardboard is my only complaint. Caramel, cocoa, butterscotch, pine, orange and loads more. This is a really great beer, but far from anything Id consider an altbier, sticke or otherwise.
I found this to be excellent and couldnt buy enough before it was gone.  An impressive, full bodied alt with roasted malt and hop aroma and flavor.  Spicy lingering hop aftertaste.

Bottle: pours a redish brown with a thick, frothy white head, aroma of hops, caramel and roasted malts, taste is malty as would be expected, lots of burnt caramel flavor as well, a nice bitter aftertaste as well, fairly full mouthfeel.  Pretty good stuff.

This has to be a really old bottle because it poured an opaque orangy color with barely any head. Flavor seems a bit oxidized. Overall this isnt a fair rating, because im positive this is a really old bottle.
Bottle. Brown pout with a small head. Roasted malt aroma and taste. hops lingering in the back. Not bad
Another beer shared by Robert!!! Overall different but good. Brownish in color. Taste was roasted malts, a little dry and hoppy.  Sweet as well. Medium texture. Good beer. Thanks again robert!

(USA) Got this Brew from fellow Knight (afireinside96) thx bro!!!  Hazy brown color with sm -tan head. There is a nice caramel aroma to this one, with a mild roasted flavor. the finish was a bit dry and the palate was bitter,  but overall pretty damn good.

Our taster was a bottom of the beer case find as "afireinside" bellow.  Dark amber pour with tan head that was gone pretty quickly.  Dry malts and a little spicy.  A tinge of hops and some bitterness but I think the edge was off of this one.  Its a shame but I guess thats it for this, would have liked to try fresh.

found this bottle the other day at a local six pack shop.best by 8/02/2006. how bad could it be? lets see....

pours a murky amber-brown with a thin tan head that quickly recedes into a thin layer of foam on top. smells earthy and of some caramel. flavor is bitter and roasted with some of the hops making their presence felt. surprisingly good for being 2 years past its prime. a hint of cocoa emerges mid-glass. finishes with a nice tang of piney hops. leaves a solid sheet of lace inside the glass. this one has held up really nice and it is a shame that I will never be able to have another one.

Pours a carbonated brown with a thin white head that remains for the entire brew. The aroma is sweet, toasted malt, oranges and berries. The flavor leans to the sweet side with a decent amount of sweet malt but this Alt does have a generous amount of hops to balnce the beer out somewhat. The finish is much more bitter and long than the initial taste.

(35.5cl bottle, bb Aug. 06, courtesy of Papsoe) Hazy, murky amber colour with a short, but slowly lacing tanned foamy head. Moderately sweet toast-malty, slightly yeasty nose with caramel and shy herbal, slightly woody hoppy notes in the background. Quite bitter flavour, almost full bodied with a soft carbonation. Toasty malty taste with caramel and notes of liquorice, even a very subtle (berry-)fruity tail is detectable; quite dry and bitter, toasty and herbal hoppy finish with a noticeable alcoholic note. Uncommon Alt in the Sticke-style, all in all not bad and it seems to mature quite well (22.03.08).

Special thanks to ilovedarkbeer for this underated retired brew. Marked to "enjoy by Aug 01 06." My first expiriance with Altbier. Aroma is heavy bready malts with an undertone of spicy orange hops and dried fruits. Appearence includes some of the best lacing I have seen in a while, truly excellent. Head is a largish tan with good retention. Body is a hazy amber-orange ala oktoberfest style brews. Taste over the long duration ends bitter and slightly metallicy in the aftertaste (a product of being bottle aged?). Medium body with a creamy texture and lively carbonation. I feel that it is missing some sort of boldness in the finish, but that could be due to my lack of familiarity with this type of beer. Very good, and underrated in my opinion.

12oz bottle, courtesy of artusory.  Thanks, Ryan!  Pours a murky, dirty amber color; thin, light tan color with patchy lacing; some particulates.  Pleasant amount of sticky caramel and dried fruits; sticky and slightly oxidized.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: toffee and dried caramel and dried fruits; very chewy and pleasant; the oxidation has, if anything, a relatively pleasant effect on this beer; I dont remember it being this chewy last year.  Medium, doughy and sugary finish; a bit messy and sweet at the end.

Feb. 2006 on draft at Victorys brewpub - I didnt get much of what others wrote in their reviews...and this was my FIRST beer of the night. Anyway, hazelnut crystal clear color with smallish head. Very faint aroma which was pretty nondescript. The flavor was odd. I wouldnt describe it as strong flavored, yet at the same time, Id say it was too sweet and too bitter at the same time. The mouthfeel was really carbonated...too much so for my liking and rather thin. Hops were present, but did more to bitter than to flavor. This was rather disappointing.
Aged bottle.  The shine has gone off the hops, as expected, but the closing bitterness is still there.  There is slight toffee-sweetness and biscuit and medium mouthfeel.  Nice.

Bottle. Two years aging at least.pours the color of marzen with a decent sized head that turns into just a ring. Smells like honey and malt. Mouthfeel is soft and the taste is of popcorn. Pretty good beer my first ALT.

11/15/2007:  Victory Ten Years Alt pours a murky/dirty, tawny amber-brown color that appears to be almost golden brown around the edges.  The small beige head fades away farily quickly and leaves a frothy veil on the surface.  The aroma contains sweet caramelized sugar and malt, aged fruits (roasted apples), some distant maple, and a touch of bitter hops.  The flavor is earthy and bitter.  There the same sweet caramelized maltiness in the middle that gives way to a smooth, and somewhat lengthy finish.  The spicy and bitter hops are really noticeable in the finish as they impart a lasting floral and herbal bitterness and flavor.  This bitterness also lends a nice balance to the sweetness of this beer.  A bit of alcohol is detectable and seems to grow as the beer warms (some dry apple flavors and oxidation also becomes notable).  It is still quite reserved for the 8.5% ABV that is supposedly tucked away in this brew!  The mouthfeel is quite thick and chewy, but fits well with my preferences for this style.  Overall this is a pretty good example of an Altbier that met my expectations.
12 fl. oz. bottle (Enjoy By Aug 01 06) from .  Rating #297 for this beer...
Old rating Reddish copper color. Aroma is malty, with dark fruits and wildflower honey. Flavor is fruity, dark and citrus fruits, spicy. Tasty enough.
Pours a dark brown with ruby hints. Nice thik head, hoppy aroma. Almost a chewy mouthfeel, plenty of malt sweetness cut by some good hops. Good stuff.
Nice dark tan head. Interesting sequence of flavors ending in bitterness. Liked the caramel malt aroma. It really grew on me.
Dark copper appearance light minimal tan head nice spice and fruit aroma. Flavor was spicy fruity lightly malty nice mild flavor..

Beautiful amber color. Aroma of caramel. Strong mouthfeel, strong taste of dark caramel, almost burnt sugar, molasses. Good and powerful, but the bitterness in the end is too strong.

Victory Ten Years Alt was an interesting Alt beer. It poured an almost brown colored body with an off white head. The aroma was pleasant with notes of spices, and malts. The taste was malty but with a notable smoky finish. This isnt a bad alt but I didnt enjoy the smoky finish in my alt.
Sweet malt and hops aroma with a faint earthy character.  Dark copper in color with faint head.  Sweet body, but a bit drier than the schwelmer purchased a week earlier.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2007 Bottle: Dark amber or golden, but almost brown with the barest of heads.  I swear this smells like pancake syrup.  Super tangy ... damn near grapefruity, yet bready.  Disappointing offering from Victory.

Cloudy mohogany color with an off-white head and a good amount of yeast settling at the bottom.  Aroma is a mix of honey, nuts, and slightly sweetened bread.  Taste is nutty, lightly sugared, and just a bit bitter from some floral hops.  I really should have tried it in its prime, but this one still holds up

Bottle.  Ive been holding this one so I could compare it to the homebrew Alt that I made last year...  This one wins!  I wouldnt consider this a normal alt, however... Much more of a caramel color than any others that I have had (most were darker brown) and also a good bit stronger and sweeter.  This is hoppy like most Victory beers are and is quite a brew.  Im glad I saved this one.  Nice creamy quality to this one and good carbonation bite.  NIce beer

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2010 Bottle.  Altbiere are meant to be consumed extremely fresh, and while this is a few months past its prime, Im happy just to get my hands on the bottle (Thanks, Jason).  Aroma is sweet and malty, light yeast with brown sugar, toasted caramel with light hops.  Amber body with light carbonation and a short soapy tan head.  Taste is very dry, earthy, slightly astringent, darkly malty and lightly bitter with a nice hop-yeast combination.  Somewhat metallic alcohol is too far up front.  Faint dark fruitiness and biscuity malt.  Oxidized a touch.  Light spiciness.  Medium body with a relatively pleasant mf.  Aftertaste (in what should be a perfect session beer) is ruined slightly by the booziness.    Style concerns aside, this is still enjoyable as of late May 2007. [May 26 2007: 6-4-7-3-14]
Another one of these in a trade.  Bottle, best by May 07, here in June 2010.  Cloudy brown with light red highlights, still has good carbonation, soapy beige head.  Sweet malty nose seems to have a hint of what I call the spaghetti funk.  A little roast and perhaps even some smoke.  Strong bitterness, a little alcohol and band-aid astringency.  Airy, very mild oxidation but still holding up relatively well.  Dark, earthy, maybe some plum and pitted fruit, but the surprise here is the dark, charred, burned notes, and the lasting and relatively high level of bitterness.  Sticky malts.  Medium-full body.  The dark side of human endeavor, much evil still lurks in this treat. [6-3-6-3-12]

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2007 12 oz bottle via Tomdecapolis (thanks!). This pours a semi-hazy reddish amber with an average size beige head. Nose is fruity and yeasty. Taste is nutty, buttery and bitter with a grapefruity finish. Alc is a bit hot. Metallic aftertaste. Body is medium, carbonation high. Not to style.  Dont care much for this.

Corked 3 litre bottle [2005] poured a lightly hazy copper with a small lingering amber head. Aromas of oxidation, fruitiness and a hint of carmel. Palate was light bodied and smooth. Flavors of fruitiness, carmel, toffee and sweet malt with a crisp dry lingering malty finish.

12 oz bottle: Slightly cloudy, medium dark amber/copper color with smallish light tan head. Aroma is full of rich toasted caramel and highly kilned malts, touch of orange and lemon, bit of vanilla. Flavor is malty, lots of caramel, bit of citrus and herbal hops, with a mildly sweet finish, bit thin in the palate. Hides it alcohol remarkably well. Overall a very nice brew . . . though Im not an expert on style guidelines, it seems a bit citrusy and hoppy for an alt, but still good.
Malty sweet nose, lovely nutbrown color, low sticky head. Toasted malt flavors, spicy hoppy end that dries. Lingering bitter. Metallic feel. Strong--too much for an alt. Good but not really and Alt.

Small, slightly irregular brownish head over hazy foxy-amber beer. Extremely malty nose, some kind of diet (corn) flakes, caramel; and all of it very intense, on the verge of astrigent (or at least its nasal counterpart). Malt syrup. Oxydized malts... cant find a BBD... Again a sweet, grain-derived syrup as malt- or cornsyrup. But with discernible oxydation. Theres no hops imprint, even when the overall flavour certainly isnt as sweet as the "syrup" would impose on itself. Quite sweet anyhow. Ends a bit leafy, earthy, nutty. Slight, portwine-like viscosity: medium bodied at least. Dont understand about the oxydation. Certainly less fine-malted than a Schumachers (let alone their Latzen!), and Zum Uerige contains about 3x as many German hops...
Amber color and medium body. Aroma is mostly malt, a bit on the sour side. Excellent lingering bitterness.

Pours a dark brown color. Thin scuzzy head on top. Kind of cloudy. Bits of stretchy, cobweeby lace on the side of the glass. Nose is loaded with earhty malts and hints of peat.

Flavor is a solid malt backbone. Holds up well. Spring-like hops. Malts have kind of a nutty, earth-like quality. Not quite peaty. Actually reminds me a bit of a scotch. Medium mouthfeel. Hops come out a bit more as it warms. Victory needs to brew some more of this beer

Draught:  Weak medium-sweet aroma of floral hops and caramel malts.  Poured dark amber/brown with a small, creamy, off-white head.  Opaque.  Good lacing.  Flavor was medium sweet though not bitter.  Tasted of toasting, nuts, and caramel malts.  Dry finish.  Average carbonation.  Medium body.  Dry texture.  Overall, Id prefer their regular alt or a Long Trail.  Does not taste as good as it smells.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2008 FANTASTIC! I loved this beer because its so convoluted. There are just too many flavors to sequester. Perhaps this beer has the best marriage of malts and hops Ive ever experienced, both are very heavy and almost overbearing, but there is so much of each that the beer melts together in a smooth, hoppy, complex, experience.
the most recent victory tried here, nice and thick, a lil alcohol heavy. the flavor doesnt overpower and seems to have a unique balance.

Pours a clear orange brown with a little white head.  The aroma is a tangy spicy malt with husky tones and grassy hops.  The flavor is tangy and sharp.  Grassy bitter hops followed by a malt flavor that then gives way to a sticky alcohol finish which surprisingly hands back control to a balanced malt and hop hit.  There is also some smokyness in the malt finish.  There are strong flavors which ride the edge, but dont cross the border into harshness.

Pours a deep copper color, nicely carbonated, with half an inch of soft off white foam. Good head retention, but the lacing clings only briefly then slides down into the glass. An alcoholic malty aroma rises from the glass.

Nicely bold and dry/sweet blend of malt, with the dry winning out. Scratch that, the dry dominates. A hint of sweetened black tea shows up briefly, then the lightly floral hop bitterness comes in. So does a trace of tobacco. Medium body, alcoholic, gentle carbonation.
Got some sweet malt in the aroma.Pours a medium copper with an off white head.Some slight roasted malt in the flavor.Medium mouthfeel with a big malt finish.
THIS BEER SURPRISED ME.  iT WAS KINDA OF A BLEND OF HOPDEVIL, AND STROM KING.  GOOD AROMA, SMOOTH TASTE, oi HAD IT AT THE BREWERY ON THEIR 10 YEAR ANNIVERSARY
Lots of caramel malt and mollasses--slightly vinuous.  Hazy mahogany in appearance with a full palate.  The taste is exaclty as expected from the aroma with more toasted malts in the finish.

Had this a few times and now that I have started cleaning out my rating notes its time to add it to the site. Pours out a slightly off clear amber/dark copper color with a medium sized head. Aroma is of slightly sweet malts with a touch of grassy hops. Flavor is complex with a good balance, some earthy flavors with caramel and some hops. Finish has a slight alcohol bite. Solid beer and not a style I would have expected for an anniversary beer.

Pours with a cloudy amber-brown body topped by a medium thick head with lots of lacing.  Its sweet and malty to start with a very slight roasty note, turning bitter and hoppy in the finish.  Medium bodied, tingly on the tongue and a touch of dryness.

Pours a really nice looking mahogany, with a one finger head that fades to a thin swirling cap and ring, leaving behind a decent lacing.

Smell; slightly nutty, with almonds and bits of walnuts. Theres a subtle vanilla with a little bit of chocolate, and some really nice earthy notes.

Taste; lots of caramel malts upfront in this one, with slitghly bitter nuts, and some raisins and figs. The chocolate and vanilla are there but not to strong, with some floral German hops in there, and just a touch on the bitter side. Mouthfeel is medium bodied and a little bit drying, with a pretty good drinkability. Wish I had picked up a sixer of this instead of just the one bottle.

As has been stated by others, you gotta love the fact that Victory brewed an Alt for their Tenth, a style thats not really all that common.

text: Bottle thanks to Engelsmann. Clear red/brown - white head. Bread, berries, caramel, hoppy, citrus, garpe, light metallic - bad storage ??

12 ounce bottle from...mmm, dont remember, somewhere in Wisconsin, summer 2006, served at cellar temperature in a Fitgers pint glass.  Deep dirty/ruddy caramel-brown hue with a creamy, lasting off-white bubbly head that laces well....roasty aroma, a bit lactic, fruity (tart apples and peaches) and growing in caramelized maltiness with warmth.....very sweet, full and thick on the tongue, burnt & caramelized sugars playing nicely off an acerbic dark roastiness with pleasant light herbal touches....again a bit of lactic sourness is noted, probably this is a little old though that may be my fault; not enough to really detract from what is a solid American alt that would probably be a real treat on tap on a mild spring day.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2008 Pours ruby/copper color with a large head. Good lacing. Aroma is sweet, dark fruits, cherries, caramel malts and spicy hops. Medium body.  Tangy sweet fruit finish (long). Really good beer.

Complex, layered, balanced experience. Sweet than tangy than bitter than dry. Tingles the taste buds throught the finish. Earthy, musty, roasty malt, hops, apple, rasin, spicy resin, chocalate. Noticable alcohol burn. I guess I like alt afterall.

Ive not had very many altbiers, and am not sure this beer fits within the category.  While it was certainly pretty pleasant, I found this beer to much more closely resember a dunkelweiss than an altbier.

This beer pours a light brown body and with a very fizzy and short-lived white head.

The aroma is a very sweet maltiness, like a dunkelweiss.

Aroma is more sweet maltiness, and also reminiscent of a dunkel.

Mouthfeel is full-bodied and appealing.

Bottle, August 2006. At 8.5% this can hardly be regarded as typical of the style but its certainly an interesting beer.  Attractive bronze/copper colour. Bags of rich malt throughout. Touches of chocolate and liquorice in the flavour. Full, but very smooth mouthfeel. Alcohol is not too intrusive. There is a fair degree of sweetness here but I found I could tolerate it better than I normally can.

Bottle.   Pours a clear dark amber color with a small, rapidly dissipating white head.   Aroma of malt, sugar, spice.   Flavor of caramel, sugar, something spicy, roasted grain, floral.   Palate is medium bodied, medium carbonation, sweet, dry finish.   Pretty good.
Great looking. Very enjoyable.  High alcohol version sticke alt that captures the alt character I love, the slightly sweet, rich, roast malt up front completely giving way to a nice dry bite finish.

Big thanks to Sneagrams3 for the trade.  Pours amber / garnet with a cream colored head.  The aroma has sweet caramelized malt with a cinnamon-like spice - very clean and full.  Medium / full body that is slick and has light carbonation.  The taste starts with earthy, but clean caramelized malt and light sourness. Then some of the cinnamon spice appear followed by some spicy hops that appear only briefly on the finish.  There is a lingering earthy malt that sticks around as well as traces of abv.  Very nicely done.

bottle-thanks to vyvvy for the sample of this unique alt.  pours lighty hazy red amber with a small soapy white head.  lightly grainy and slightly alcoholic nose with lots of toasted grains and a nice yeast twang.  really smells like an alt that has been jacked up a few notches.  hops?  i didnt get the hops that many were mentioning.  flavors are malty, toasted grains, sweet alcohol, and a nice yeast kick on the finish with the lingering carmel malts and light grain husks.  Really stands by style as a good, amped up, representation of this unique style.  very good job Victory!

Despite being close to the expiration date, this beer has kept a hefty dose of hop aromas, translating into a potent leafy, laurel, old socks and earthy perfumes (better than it sounds!). Kinda tea like within its slightly citrusy (orange) boundaries. Nevertheless, the hops maintain more of a bittering than aromatic function, letting rather sweet berries and figs fruitiness shine through its rather toasty foundations. Surprisingly lean bodied, easily drinkable for that magnitude and the alcohol is a no-show. Pretty good.

Clear amber/brown with a small, creamy, light tan head that fades quickly. Nose of bold, resiny hops over biscuity, toasty graham cracker malt. Malt over hops in the flavor, same notes. Balanced, medium body. Excellent altbier.

12oz bottle.  Filtered and clear with a lovely deep amber hue.  Sparse clinging white head.  Fruity hops and medium malts are apparent in the aroma.  Bready and appley with a touch of raisin sweetness in the nose.  Medium bodied and super dry.  Medium malt roast and a great woody, earthy bitter chocolate malt charavter.  Lively and tingling.  But texturally layered and sophisticated.  Sweet malts, Tart flavors that meld into bitter and dry hoppy finish.  It hits all aspects of the tongue.  Caramel malts, as said before, bittersweet chocolate, a well hidden alcohol burn that becomes more apparent as the beer warms and the other flavors and palate subside.  Nice musty note as the glass is raised to my lips, and in the mouth for just a split second.  Quickly raplaced by the dry, hoppy monster that is spicy and has a subtle grassy flavor and aroma.  The finish leaves the mouth sticky but somewhat puckered.  The dryness is counteracted by the sticky piney, resinous hop profile.  If this is an alt bier, I love alt biers!  Great complexity, great melding of layered flavors and a truly wonderful offering from a great brewery!

Autumn Fire Orange with White Ring.  Sweet Malt and Caramel...Burnt/Roasty Character on the Nose. Underlying Fruit Notes and Hop Character...Overladen with Roasted Malt, Caramel...Fig/Bread Notes..Dry and a Bit Bitter Ending....Quite Drying After a Few Sips.. Medium Mouthfeel.  Alcohol Well Hidden. Nice Enjoyable Alt.  I Prefer a Thicker, Heartier Malty Alt, but This One is Nothing to Scoff At.

Any first impressions?
-A veil of foam garnishes the murky copper.
-Cheesy hops and strawberry sweetness intrigue the nostrils.
-Candied fruitiness and noble herbal hops keep the tongue interested throughout.
-The low carbonation and well-nourished maltiness produce a comfortable mouthfeel.

What if you dig deeper?
-Herbal hops healthily linger.
-Raspberries expand the fruity spectrum.
-The alt heritage is still felt even though its been pushed into doppel sticke territory.
-Alcohol is no obstacle for this well-crafted sipper.

Bottle; best before Aug. 2006.

Poured a murky brownish orange from the bottle with a frothy, lacing slightly tan head.  Malty aroma, but also spicy.  Yeasty and grainy flavor, slightly malty.  Astringent afer taste in which the alcohol is obvious.  This beer might be better if the alcohol was mellowed.

12oz bottle via trade with puzzl.  Aroma: Sweet candy-like aroma.  Light biscuity malt,   nutmeg-like spice, green apples.   Appearance:  Deep copper in color and quite hazy.  Off-white head was medium sized and foamy with little retention.  Not much lacing.  Flavor:  Pretty hoppy for an altbier.  Light caramel and biscuit are trampled by hop flavor and bitterness.  Earthy and spicy hops with some pine and floral, too.  Bitterness kicks in early and stays well after the finish.  Palate:  Medium bodied.  Medium carbonation.  Overall:  This one didnt work for me.  Not enough malt character to offset the hops.  Is this really supposed to be an altbier?  Not even close.

Bottle from JHop.  Pours a hazy tawny with spare fizzy off-white diminishing head.  Aroma is average malt (bread, caramel, nutty), average to heavy hops (flowers, pine), light yeast (dough) with notes of alcohol (average), grape and honey.  Average duration, moderate sweetness, acidity and bitterness and ends bitter.  Medium bodied, alcoholic texture and fizzy.

Quite cloudy, reddish amber color with an orangish tan head that lets me know they used Munich malt.  Cotton candy in the aroma further confirming the use of Munich malt.  Also, some very earthy, almost dirty hops and lots of sweet caramel and milk with just a touch of licorice.  Flavor is dominated by  a strong smoke then also some caramel, an earthy, hoppy dryness throughout the profile, and a solid bitterness in the finish.
Dark garnet red. Nice thin white head and lacing. Aroma is rich and spicy. Almost belgian in nature. flavor is rich and warm. Strong flavor. Big heavy flavor with just a touch of alcohol.

Pouring from this bottle with a deep copper color, this is a pretty beer. The thin white head created a thin scum on top. The aroma has some peanuts and a little bit of caramel. The taste has a lot of caramel and a little bit of peanut butter. There is also a little bit of apple core. Wow, the alcohol is not detected at all. An interesting brew.

12 oz. bottle via trade with hopdog - Pours a deep amber color with a nice size off white head.  Has a earthy malt and slightly oxidized aroma.  This bottle was 2 months past its "Enjoy by" date.  Light lacing is left behind as the head settles.  Has a sweet caramel malt flavor.  Alcohol isnt really detectable.  Medium body.  A decent alt.  Thanks Steve.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2007 On tap at the Muddy Pig.  Metallic, coppery shade with an inviting, holiday aroma of cinnamon and apples, like sitting by the fireplace anticipating dessert.  Sadly it falls apart as a strange combination of flavors and an inhospitable mouthfeel make it much less of a treat than it seems to promise.  Paper is foremost, followed by pumpkin, caramel, soap, and sweat.  The bitterness of its spicy hops seemed too rough is rough edged.  Steel wool in the mouth.  Slow failure.
Poured a copper amber with off white head. Some bitter and wood-earthy.  Slight trace of the %. Nice brew.

Nothing incredibly special.  Cloudy coppery color.  Light head. Strong aroma, with some definite citrus and strong malt notes.  Nicely bittered, although unbalanced.  There is an unmistakable tannin flavor that slides by the back of the tongue on the way down.  Lots of carbonation left it feeling lighter than id expected.

Pours a coppery amber color with a tiny white head.  Aroma is tangy with hops and malts present.  Taste is bitter and tangy with hints of roasted hops,wood chips,malt and a touch of lemon.  Decent but nothing spectacular.
a little bitter, sweet, dry, malty, a good beer I would buy it again, has a chocolaty taste to it.

Bottle. Dark amber with light ruby hue. Small head with decent lacing. Clean malty, woody aroma, refreshing clean hoppy add on, woody roast finish. Quiet bitter, woody accented ale .Dark roasted malts, dry finish.

Aroma has caramel,butterscotch and malt, a slight alcohol presence, chestnut, pours a small toffee head. Flavour has a fine malt underpinning, almonds, some woody notes. good hops. Full bodied, complex, well balanced warming. pleasantly bitter Terrific! Thank You Radek!

12 oz. bottle from Styles.  nice appearance of a sligtly hazy dark amber with a fast fading tan head.  aroma is of mild caramel, but flavor has a strange bitterness to it which is not off-set by the mild carame & toffee notes.  if this is truly an 8.5% abv beer, the slcohol is hidden decently.  unusual, drinkable, but not something I care to re-visit anytime soon.
clear amber color, lacey tan head, roasty malt nose, flavor is defined by lime, its like a beer version of a gin and tonic, a very interesting and different alt worth investigating

Jewel like amber color with a thin khaki colored head.  Dark brown sugar and rye bread nose.  Very malty beer with caramel, some plum fruit, and burnt pumpernikel toast.  Finish is an almost dust hop.

Super malty aroma, I was expecting a mean doppelbock-tasting beer. Pruney, woody.  Buffered acidity, parched grain, light cocoa, chalkiness.  Slow-building alcohol and woody bitterness, which never gets out of hand. A fairly distinctive brew, but it lacks the grassy "German" character that I look for in an alt.  Finish built and built and eventually became intolerable.
UPDATED: DEC 16, 2006 I had this when it 1st came out and didnt really care for it. Had a bottle last night and it was pretty good. Nice spicy hop flavors as well as roasted malt character.

a very nice beer to sip slowly and savor.  Not the best verison of this style but it is a fairly good reprsentation.  I might stick with other victory brews over this one thought. (ie. hop wallop, hop devil, golden monkey)

A great strong brew.  Has a nice dark golden/amber color with a medium off-white head.  Aroma is slightly floral with a definate hop pressence.  Taste is very assertive, with a strong hop flavor at first, giving way to a strong, but not overpowering alcohol flavor, and nice smooth finish.  Also got a bottle that says, "Enjoy by Aug 01 2006," and its September.
Nice amber color, small head leaving some laces on the glass. Light sweet malt and caramel nose. Some grain taste, medium hoppy that lasts medium long. Ok - nothing special but solid.

Not sure how well this one cellars, just noticed the bottle says, "Enjoy by Aug 01 2006 and I am pretty sure I bought it after that date. Well, here goes, pours a cloudy copper color with long lasting thick foamy head. Aroma of sweet hops with notes of pear, kind of grainy. Taste is heavy, spicy, finishing with a bitter dryness. Very roasted bitter, slight warm finish.
Bottle. Quite a strong alt, with a fair bit of caramelly sweetness and slight nuttiness, finish has some grassyness from the hops, but the malt sweetnes probably stands out the most.
Bottle. Amber colour with a little head. Aroma of sweetness, candy, caramel and heavy Americans hops. Very bitter and hoppy flavour, ends up bitter and dry, not very classic.

What a great beer! Poured from the bottle a dark brown/red/orange colorwith a good off white head. Earthy aroma, malts and grains. Full bodied and full of flavor. Initially, the hops wake up the mouth, followed by the mellowing sweetness of roasted malt and finishing with a dry hop bitterness. A complete package of taste and texture without even noticing the alcohol content. I am only sorry I bought a single bottle. Dangerously tasty.

12 oz bottle, thanks to Firemoose. Pours an orangish brown with a small, cola like head. Aroma is wood (oak maybe) with some toasted caramel and some dried fruits. Taste is sweet and cardboard with some dried pineapple. The malts are roasty all right along with a nice nuttiness. Soem cocoa and chocolate in there as well. Decent hop bitterness.

Wow! This one is kind of vicious. It has some nice caramel hops but is accentuated by some bitter hops and the alcohol is noticeable. I do love hops and bitterness so I enjoy it but it isnt too balanced. The aroma is strong as far as floral hops are concerned, and the flavor has a nice roasted hop crunchy malted feel to it. The complexity is here but Im not sure how well the pieces dance with each other. I do have to say, this is one of the best cases I ever bought for $19.95 and the fact the beer suposedly went out of date 8-1-06 does not seem to have made a difference.

bottle . . pours cloudy dark brown . . light white head . . aroma is hoppy, woody, citrus, toffee . . taste is spicy, hoppy, caramel, creamy with a little bit of a bitter after taste left with toffee . . alcohol is VERY well hidden . . nice beer . .
Caramel and fruit aroma, with a bit of smoke. Flavor is hot alcohol, but has a nice hop kick I wasnt expecting, as I didnt catch mich in the aroma. Interesting, well made.

355ml bottle obtained in a trade with <a
href=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?U target=blank>zathrus13, thanks Jeff.  Best Before Aug 02/06.  Golden orange in colour, murky, light tan coloured head, lots of lacing.  The aroma had lots of citrus (lemons mainly), light caramel sweetness, nicely hopped.  The flavour was quite hoppy (some pine, oranges), balanced by caramel malts, some lemon tang, yeasty, great sweetness.  HIgh bitter mouthfeel, medium body, high carbonation.  Finishes with a lingering moderate bitterness with some citrus and caramel.  Really quite a bitter Altbier, very good stuff.

Not the best Victory brew Ive had, but still a great beer. Crisp hoppiness throughout that linger nicely on the palate, with slight sweet malt for balance. Nice everyday brew. Too bad they dont make it everyday.

The first beer in my quest to give lower ratings so as to expand my rating range. This was a tasty brew, mellow, strong malts and a minty, hoppy but not bitter aftertaste. Went down smooth, though with a powerful alcohol kick. Pretty rich in the malt arena, though not sweet, with nice complexity. A very good beer.

Bottle.
Cloudy orange coloured with a white head.
Aroma of malts, fruits, caramel, yeast and hops.
Flavour of malts, caramel, hops and pine needles

draught:  My first altbier so I dont know what its flavor chacteristics are, but I really liked this beer.  aroma of dark malts and spicy hops up front.  The beer was served in a chalice with a nice half an inch of head, that laced like no other.  Flavor was great.  Rich roasted malt with a balance of spicy hops.  Palate was rather full and slightly oily.  I wish that I had some more of this stuff.  Cheers.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Slightly hazy amber golden with an off-white head. Aroma of caramel and aroma hops. Fairly full body with lots of caramel malt and a very bitter finish. But Altbier? At 8.5% ABV?? No way. 160806
Bottle. Orange colour with a small tan head. Malty, fruity, hoppy aroma and taste. Medium body with a dry finish. Dose not taste like a alt bier.

Alts are hard to come by in my neck of the woods so I was mighty happy to find this brew. From a bottle, this pours a clear, dark amber with ruby edges. Minimal off-white head. Aroma is full of yeasty baked bread & a nice whiff of spicy hops. First taste is caramelly, nutty malt.  Finish is long, dominated by peppery hops that provide a pleasant lingering bitterness.<!-- br --><!-- br -->  What do you get when you cross a Marzen with an ESB? I dont know but Ill bet it would be pretty close to this very nice brew.

bottle. Pours a hazy light brown.  medium carbonation on this beer.  The aroma is of earthy, resinous hops, but with alot of sweet malt also.  Taste is malty, slightly fruity, some apples, and just enough flavor hops to balance the beer out well without making it too bitter for an alt.
[Bottled, thanks chris_o!] Amber colour. Ashy nose. Sweetish with clean, rounded mouthfeel and medium body. Finishes with some salty licorice. A bit shallow in character.
Bottle. Pours orangey red with an off white head. Aroma is malt and pine with tanginess. Flavor is Caramel, tangy, pine, and malt. I can detect the alcohol in this one.
Good shot at the style with maybe just a little too much alcohol for me. Sweet citrus notes along with decent malt character. Very complex, yet smoothed out. Nice drinking, even my wife liked it.

Without even thinking about it, I opened this a day before my 10-year wedding anniversary.  I also opened it while moving into a new house, having spent four hours loading a 26 foot truck all by myself and mostly emptying it by myself for another four hours.  It was an incredibly welcome relief, but not only that, I thought this was great.  Rich chestnut brown color.  Beautiful caramels but mountains of assertive hops, first metallic but then simply flowing into a very flavorful combination of citrus and herbs.  Still retains that essential alt malt character, with impressive balance.  Great body, well supported and tingling the mouth too.  Im not sure how close this is to style (nor do I much care) but it is the best alt Ive ever had.
Very excellent offering from Victory, as usual.  A strong Alt brew that doesnt have an overdone sweetness tone, but a balanced malt and smooth flavor.
Copper colored, with a creamy off-white head. Nice caramel aroma, with some herbal notes, too. Piney flavored, with some sweet toffee and caramel flavors, too. Vaguely savory finish. Tasty.

I have had this beer several times now. I had it on-tap Friday night at the Victory party, On-tap Saturday night at the victory party and from the wooden barrel. I am now having it in the bottle and it is just as good. In fact I enjoyed it even more at home. I didnt take notes previously so I do not know if it really is better in the bottle or just the fact that there are less enthusiastic distractions in my home; and the relaxed experience allows me to focus on the beer better at home. Nonetheless, those of you who had this beer at the party, do not fear that youll get something less in the bottle. I did worry it wouldnt be as good, and it is great!

I my opinion this beer has absolutely no faults whatsoever. It is an instant favorite of mine.

Appearance: It is a dark amber color that is pretty much transparent (very enticing just by appearance). A nice whit head and decent lacing. 

Smell: This beer portrays a big but gentle sweet malt aroma. It smells of caramel, brown sugar, birch or cherry wood, a sprinkle of spices and a hint of brandy.

Taste: The flavor is dominantly a brown sugar sweet malt. It also featured caramel, a hint of molasses, a dash of pepper and just a hint of cherry and apple. I know this beer was not aged in a wooden barrel, (I had that version at Victorys party) but it still seemed to have a hint of that wood flavor like in a Woodford Reserve Bourbon. As a huge fan of Bourbon and Brandy all I could think of was my dream come true, a whiskey beer. That does not mean you could taste the alcohol. The 8.50% ABV was completely masked; buried so deep that you would never imagine it was more than 5% until you finish the second one and realize it :)
The hop character is firmly yet discretely present. The floral hops show them self only through mild spices and grannysmith apple or lime peel presence found alongside the pepper flavor. Not overly green just enough to keep it nice and crisp. What a perfectly balanced flavor. Excellent!

Mouthfeel: It is smooth and slick at the beginning and the end with a hint of peppery crispness just before the swallow.

Drinkability: I can drink this till I fall over! Wow. I am flabbergasted. It is so smooth an yet crisp; sweet yet bitter, it is IMO, everything a beer should be!
What else can I say. It is an absolute must have. Try it and see what you think!

Hope this is helpful.
Cheers!

Bottle. Fermented fruit aroma and what seemed to be a wet dish rag there also. Caramel colored body with tan head. Decent pale citrus flavor the leaves a somewhat dry grapefruit aftertaste. Decent beer.

Bottle poured caramel with a thick creamy head.
Aroma is sweet malt, hops and ripe fruits.
Flavor is sweet and citrusy with a big citrus and slightly metalic finish.
No skimping on the hops.  I like the aroma but doesnt last long.  I think the hops overpower the flavor, hiding its fruit flavors.  Burnt orange hazy appreance.
Pours dark amber into an altbier glass.  Spicy fruit aromas. Slight off-white head skims surface.  Creamy and full with upfront, creamy malt notes which turns quickly to a bitter grapefruit finish.

thanks to pineypower for the bottle. It pours dark brown with some red highlights and a one finger off white head. Nice aroma that reminds you of honey or molasses. Its medium bodied w/ a slightly malty flavor. Nice easy drinking beer.

200th rater.  Bottle provided by Willblake at the NYRBG.  Amber, copper color.  Nice aroma of hoppiness and black bread at once.  Taste is zingy bready.  A bit thin.  A nice hoppy alt, different.  Medium-low body.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Bottle at NYRBG. Deep amber brown in color with a nice fluffy off white head. Malty and hoppy aroma. Citrusy earthy, spicey hops. Malty and hoppy flavor. Caramel spicey notes. Sweet. Medium to full bodied. Dry bitter finish. Nice beer. Very drinkable.

This poured a deep hazy amber-brown color, with a nice 1-inch white head. The aroma was of both hops and malt. I enjoyed this - it had the perfect mix of spice and sweet malt flavors. It finishes with a bitter hop and alcohol taste.

Bottle...poured a cloudy deep orangish brown with a nice off-white head that soon dissipated.  Citrus nose.  Spicy and grass hop palate.  Like a toned down APA with some spice.  Pretty good and would have another if I see it.

Bottle, best by Aug 2, 2006.  Poured deep copper and hazy with a small head, but it dissappeared quickly.  Caramel and citrusy hops in the nose, but its a tad thin.  Interesting flavor.  Very hoppy at first, but that backs off and a it takes a bit of caramel sweetness.  Leaves a bit of a honey taste in the mouth.  Rather sharp and a has an unexpected bite.  Im not really a fan of the finish, dry and stale.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2006 (Bottle, best before Aug 01 06)  Pours a lightly cloudy amber with a small creamy yellowish-beige head.  Aroma of caramel, nuts, and pineapple.  Flavor of nuts, toasted malt, and hops provides good balance and nice dry, bitter finish.  Excellent altbier!
Deep copper in color,slight muriness with a small off-white head. Aroma of sweet malt,touch of caramel. Flavor is bitter,clean malt that finishes dry. Medium body,overall a good alt.

12oz bottle Enjoy by Sept20 06-pours a big foamy to rocky tan head with red color.  Aroma is sweet medium malt, hint of caramel.  Taste is medium malt, alcohol, secondary hops with bitterness.  OK carbonation.

Dark reddish copper that pours almost more like a cola with lots of fizz than a head.  Either way it dies down real quick and leaves very little residue.  Aromas are sweet, malty and caramel... almost a bit syrupy with some fruit in the mix, too.  The flavor is really different than I was expecting.  The syrupy character comes through and it almost starts like a barley wine or something, but then does a head fake and things get a little funky as it settles into a bitter hop finish that could be a bit more smoothly transitioned, but I like it.  It does have a bit of an astringent alcoholic character that is a bit much at times, but then considering the ABV its really to be expected.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Rich dark amber pour under a stone khaki head with nice retention.  Malty aroma with some fruit and hops.  Because the aroma almost reminded me of a bock, I expected the flavor to be dominated by malt but it was much more balanced with a solid hop presence, some toffee, floral notes and a little vanilla.  I thought the mouthfeel was a tad watery but the finish was both sweet and pleasantly bitter.  Not one of Victorys better offerings but a solid brew nonetheless.

Nice and punchy, this one is dark, sweet, hoppy, and aromatic.  It is almost predicatble in style, however it does boast a very nice flavour for an East Coast USA beer.  It has a lot of character and a big alcohol punch.  Well crafted, nothing that I will be running back to, but well made none the less.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a clear copper colored body under a creamy one inch beige head.  Pretty decent retention.  Aroma is malt dominated, sweet with some toasted notes as well as a light hoppiness.  Flavor is sweet caramel with some toffee.  A distinct iced tea flavor comes on in the finish with a little alcohol.  Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with a sticky texture and a moderate soft, but lively, carbonation level.  This was alright, but not as crisp and complex as I was hoping for.

Poured from bottle into snifter.  Aroma is a neat blend of caramel, vanilla, and a smattering of earthy hops.  It had a hazy dark amber color and a moderately lasting tan head.  The earthy hops that I noticed in the aroma were VERY prevalent in the flavor, bordering on overpowering.  I also found the finish to be a bit tinny.  They made up for these issues by being very discreet with the ethanol flavor.  I had no idea that this was a "big" beer.  Thank you Santa!

12 oz bottle-Pours a cloudy mahogany color w/a small off white head.  Bready, grainy, grassy, roasted aroma. Heavy, overpowering hoppy flavor-too heavy. This is really like an amber IPA, or double IPA. Needs some malt finish or sweetness to balance it out. I just dont get anything out of it but big hops-needs more. A disappointment as I usually find Victory beers quite enjoyable. Well made, just not my style.

I learn more from Pigfoot by reading than by drinking:

"Appearance: clear, cherryish, tea-like color, a lovely rubyish tint, under a slim cocoa/creamy layer of foam, soon down to a slight ring. Earthy aroma, big malts, mild fruit, herbal, crisp, clean, classy. A malty explosion once on board the mouth, big caramel and dark fruit, splashes every inch of the palate. Bright caramel, rich and delicious, delights the tongue, just long enough before gently drying and fading handily away. Thats the key to this terrific brew, has all the taste and strength of a doppelbock, yet holds into well into check, with the attributes of an altbier. Taste is brighter with fruit, cherries and grapes, further in. Strength is not felt right away, but creeps along. Full-bodied, boldly flavored, well-constucted, a display of skill and imagination. Great way to celebrate 10 victorious years!"

Wow, is that 8.5% ABV right? If so, it is completely undetectable. This had a nice feel to it, a bit more thick and syrupy than I had expected. Sweet malty flavors as well, like brown sugar or something. Flavor wasnt too daring or anything, but tasty, each sip demanded a follow up. A good beer from a great brewer.

Thin frothy head of fine creamy bubbles.  Light carbonation.  Wait, a 8.5% altbier?  Yeah right.  Malty and bready aroma with some spices and a bit of sweetness from caramel or brown sugar.  Color is a murky mahagony brown.  More brown sugar and malts.  Dry pasty palate.  Kind of gritty.  Alcohol warming.  Big alcohol presence when drinking with food.  Some hops bitterness.  More caramel.  Finish is warm and smooth.  A pretty decent brew.

12 oz bottle: poured orange brown with a smallish tan head. Aroma of hops and malt with a bit of brown sugar. Flavor is barleywine-ish. Big alcohol bite. Light brown sugar and hops. Pretty good but kind of hot.

Was surprised to find this on my local shelf. Were usually the last place on the planet to get anything remotely "new". Pours cold with a murky amber appearance and a thin quickly disappearing tan head. Aroma is a nice mix of malt and hops. Palate is almost thick, with a nice hop kick in the flavor. Cant catch any presence of the alcohol in this. Quite drinkable, I may save some of these for the winter when it feels like barleywine weather... Summertime in Texas really calls for something lighter.
user_location: Waco (Buckle of the Bible Belt), Texas, USA

text:
Courtesy of Ohiodad
<!-- P -->
Aroma is caramel malt, fruit, earthy notes and a slightly Barelywine-like aroma that is hoppier than expected. Pour is amber/brown with a firm pinky thin tan head that diminished slowly. Rich, sweet caramel explodes int he fore and carries on through the middle and finish. A dollop of toffee appears through the middle ranges and the whole thing is expertly supervised by a consistent, but never domineering hops flavor. Some mild fruit and bread notes are present in the far finish. Seems pretty big for an Alt (or the ones I have had) but as a beer and it is fairly tasty.

Appearance: clear, cherryish, tea-like color, a lovely rubyish tint, under a slim cocoa/creamy layer of foam, soon down to a slight ring. 

Earthy aroma, big malts, mild fruit, herbal, crisp, clean, classy. 

A malty explosion once on board the mouth, big caramel and dark fruit, splashes every inch of the palate. Bright caramel, rich and delicious, delights the tongue, just long enough before gently drying and fading handily away.
