Taste is brighter with fruit, cherries and grapes, further in. 

Strength is not felt right away, but creeps along.

Full-bodied, boldly flavored, well-constucted, a display of skill and imagination. 
Great way to celebrate 10 victorious years!

Numerous bottles as extras. I think kramer, artusory, shadey. Anyway thanks to all. Dark copper, with minimal head. Caramel/toffe aroma up front with off-smelling fruit esters. Flavor much the same plenty of caramel, roasted grain, nuttiness, with more off fruity flavors. Becomes very harsh and astringent as it warms, really starts to detract from the score. Thin body and mouthfeel. Just another average beer.

Bottle.  Caramel copper murky appearance, thin tan head.  Nose of burnt oranges, bubble gum, sweet medicinal aromas, like pepto-bismol.  Bitter up front, intensely bitter... some juicy orange hop flavors in there with the coarse, assertive palate... flavors of orange marmalade and burnt toast.  But man, the palate... this is so not an altbier, not even close, are you kidding me?  This is a freaking amber ale that’s been hopped up.  Reminds me of the funky, chewy organic brews that Roots puts out in Portland.  As just pure flavor and aroma goes, this is OK... has some good juicyness, but the hop profile is a disaster.

Poured a clear dark copper color with a decent initial off-white, fluffy head, that laced decently. Aroma was hard to pick up at a serving temp of 50C, only citrus and light caramel. The flavor was strong, lots of caramel and light toffee. Roastedness was underplayed. Balanced by a significant amount of hops. Claims to have only German hops in it, but there was definitely a citrus twist to the hop flavor. Hot alcohol presence for an alt. An alt with extreme maltiness and hoppiness, much like a dIPA take on the alt style. This was clearly an ale and did not come across with any lager crisp/cleanness. Finish wasnt really dry enough for my liking on the alt style. Hard to rate within style, because Im most familiar with and very fond of the standard alts. This "sticke" was much like the Uerige Doppelsticke Ive had, which is a rare style even in the Dusseldorf area. How to compare this to a bottle of the Uerige that travelled over the Atlantic? Not bad, but sticky sweet and somewhat cloying, despite the hoppiness.

Thanks to Argo0 for this one!
Caramel brown body with a touch of haze under a choppy, tall, light tan head that sticks to the sides on the way down.
Bready malt aroma.  A touch of unpeeled cold bananas.
Sweet with just a bit of hop bitterness at the end of the finish.  Good body, but nothing really exciting overall.

12 oz bottle by 8/1/06.  Bubbly rust with a foamy oatmeal head.  Settles to a scum.  Brown sugar hops with some lemon.  A little dry leather.  Biting carb sours to lemon peel and lingers.   Pine and pepper.  Medium body; leaves a vodka aftertaste.

Bottle.

Head is initially small, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is medium amber.

Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, bread), lightly to moderately hoppy (apricot, grapefruit), moderately yeasty (dough), with a light note of toffee.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.

Yeast-heavy nose, not very interesting.

Bottled. Best before 8/6. Beer is a murky medium orange-amber color with a large, frothy, off-white, mostly diminishing head. The aroma is sweetly malty with a light note of toasted grain and caramel, trace of puppy chow; Hoppy with a light note of resin/pine; Yeasty with dominating moderate-to-strong notes of dough; The flavor is moderately-to-heavily bitter, moderately sweet, lightly acidic with a long, moderately bitter/grippy, warm finish. The body is light, the texture is watery and the carbonation is lively.

From a 12 oz. long neck brown bottle with a blurb on the left side of label and enjoy by date, Aug/01/06.

Made a tasty appearance, poured a hazy reddish copper with a large foamy beige head that settled into a thin foamy lacing, fair amount of sticking, medium carbonation.

Had a nice roasted malty nose, nutty and fresh german dark bready with a good herbal spiciness.

A malty crisp, slick, textured and creamy smooth medium bodied mouth feel, good drinkability.

Deliciously malty, roasted nuts and grain bready, followed by a spicy herbal hoppiness, cutting just under the malts to help maintain balance, a nice warming alcohol presence shows up towards the end and a dryish spicy and malty finish with a herbal alcohol warmth lingering in the palate.

An excellent Altbier from Victory, tasty and balanced, dangerously quaffable.

Not too bad of a way to celebrate Victorys ten-year anniversary.

Has a deep orange body with a nice, thick beige/tan (take your pick) head.  

Very hoppy and quite malty (but not too much) .

Deep copper body with minimum carbonation  and a sudsy beige head. Vinous red wine notes in the aroma plus plums, toasty bread, and alcohol. Medium, well-restrained sweetness with Munich malt character, a roasty edge, and somewhat coarse wood stem bitterness in the finish. Medium, somewhat flaccid body. Decent rendition of an alt.

Poured a dark amber with a cloudy body leaving a thick tan head in its wake. The smell is sweet initally caramel, pecan, grape juice with a freshly peeled grapefruit aroma. The taste starts with a sharp bitter bite very nice hop presence that excites the tongue. It is followed by a balancing sweetness of caramel, cooked sugar, sweetness. The finish is tannic with a whip of bitterness that has a tongue smacking presence in it. This is a great brew love this style and interpretation. Happy 10th Victory, keep up the good work!

12oz. bottle.  Murky dark orange-brown with a thin film of light tan head.  Ruddy, faintly toasty malt and spicy herbal hops in the aroma.  Heavy herbal/vegetal hop component, tapers to fairly sweet malt with caramel and toasty tones.  Lemony, grassy hop astringency in the finish with a fusel alcohol oiliness and some grain huskiness.  Mouthfeel is medium, rather dry.

12 oz. bottle, sent by awesome trader slob - thanks Bert!  This pours a cloudy medium chestnut color with a small but creamy beige head.   Aroma of toasty-sweet malts and citrus with a slight yeast and dust character.  Flavor is big time hoppy, but balanced well by the rich toasty malt undertones, hops are lemon, spruce and spice with a slight alcohol burn and a lingering citrus-astringent finish.  Mediium body and gently foamy carbonation.  Quite nice and a bit of a surprise based on my other experiences with the alt style.  Very nice!

Bottle poured out with a copper color with a large tan head.The smell was of malt,sweetness and light hops.The taste
was also refleceted in those smells,but I noticed as it got warmer it almost tasted like a barley wine.Good.
Bottle courtesy of doclock.  Pours amber with a thin tan head.  Smells of chewable vitamins, grapes and lemons.  Tastes of pine, peppers and some sweet oranges and malt.

Bottle thanks to ilinismitty. Poured a clouded brown with a gray white thin head. Sweet caramel and jelly aroma. With some nut aroma. O.k. the first taste made me wince. Hard biting flavor really surprised me. Strong herbal and grass hop presence that mixed with an alcohol bite that I do not like. There is an underlying sweetness here that is struggling in vain to show itself fully. This is strongly medicinal. A touch of licorice too. Chalky oily mouth feel, how it is both I dont know but it is. Finish is like mint and raisinets. This is not the beer for me. But I appreciate the attempt.
Ap-3 ar-7 tas-2 pal-2 ov-6

Bottle.
Mildly pleasant aroma with light amber look and thin head.
Very malty tasting with slight bitterness. The hops balance was good but intresting. Not my fav style but good tasting.

Hazy orange amber, with a small off-white head that went away quickly.  Nice aroma, lots of malt, some hops, some green apple.  Upfront, get sweet malty taste, then lots of hops, and an alcoholic finish.  Nice complex beer, delicious, worth buying.

A large, slightly off white head sat on cloudy, light brown body. The head quickly faded. The malt came through first then the hops. The aftertaste was bitter and put me off. The balance is off, leaning towards the hops.

(12 oz bottle: Obtained 01-May-06 in trade with hopdog, thanks Steve!) "Enjoy By Aug 02, 06"  Well okay, I will!!  This beer proudly displays a tall, off-white chapeau on a cloudy, deep amber body.  Emanating from the glass is a fruity, mildly sweet, grainy and caramely aroma that is less pleasing that I was expecting because it is also has a dirty-laundry aroma.  Whatever short-comings I find in the nose, they are erased when I take a sip of this wonderfully flavorful beer.  Actually, the first thing I notice on my initial sip is the exceptional, full-bodied mouthfeel.  Wow, this is almost chewy!  The flavor is very malty, toasty, and quite hoppy and bitter, nothing shy about it.  The toasty malts turn a bit bready in the finish.  Hops are more European in style rather than the citrusy type Im used to out here.  The head gradually settles to a wide ring, but leaves large pathes of lace that resemble ice crystals on the window on a cold winters day.  While the beer seems a bit overstated for the style, its a superb beer thats more than worthy to represent the 10-year anniversary of Victory.

Bottle is actually far better than the tap pours Ive had. Im not a huge fan of alt beers but this is a really complex, even subtle interpretation that combines hints of rich (occasionally sour) fruits with a bold maltiness. Sounds like it might suck, right? Not so. Its really good, with a rich, burnished quality.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2009 12 Oz Bottle. Aroma of rich, earthy grains, as a loaf of French Meadow Whole Grain Boule can be, with supple nitrogenous sugars and yielding yeasts. At first, the aroma carries a lightly acerbic touch of lemongrass and sour peaches, mingled with a dab of soy sauce and minted bourbon. Pour of heavily clouded richly ruddied amber, with sunset fire fringes and tawny glints. Lacy cream head of deep ivory. Wow! I was not ready for that intense malt burst right on the tongue. It has such delectable sweetness and gentle caramels. Lightly toasted grains with sweet lemon thyme and basil stems. Good chewiness. Theres a touch of toast and some aged wheat with a spot of light yeast spice. As the beer sits in your mouth, it gracefully grows into a refreshing bite of grassy pears and sweet marmalade rinds, but then defines itself a little over the edge with an almost parching effect. The alcohol is barely perceptable, with a graduale glowing effect. Bravo! This is outstanding, stylistcally.

Hard to put a finger on this one. Its good, just different. Sort of hoppy and bitter with a slightly thick sweetness. Had a strange aftertaste. I havent had many of this style though, could just be me.
Bottle- Pours a  dark brown muddy color. Small off white heead. Crisp clean but flavorful body. Hints of chocolate and dark fruit present themselves nicely with a german hop finish.
Clear Dark Orange. 1 finger head. Malty cherry nose. Little dry on the palate. Good balance between malt and hop. Quite enjoyable.

Nice deep ruby/rust color. Off-white creamy regular-sized head.
Malty bread aroma with some allspice.
Slightly bready malt with a touch of hops, some estery sweetness and cinnamon spice.
Good overall and balanced beer.

Pour is hazed amber with a tthin dense tan head...dark fruits and grain pour out of the glass and into my nose...alcohol is quite apparent in the flavor...along with some more dark fruits...alcohol becomes even more prevalent as it warms...finish is lingeringly bitter...

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2006 24.07.06  Re-rate This beer has become stinky with a sour body odor aroma.  Background has gained notes of butter and legumes (lima beans), peppery spices, and soy beans.  Long, lingering spice ans sourness persists.  I still think its authentic, but Im less enthused about where its headed.  5 4 7 3 12, RB score averaged.  05.16.06  12oz bottle, undated but apparently a special release for the anniversary.  Hazed stuff, ruby-copper colored with glowing amber highlights.  the head is small but lasting in a tan film.  Aroma is encouraging with a round mixture of earth (mineral, wet grain field), spice (black pepper), and fruit.  The hops are potent enough that they mask any trace of the high ABV.  The flavor is exciting as it fills the mouth and returns strongly in the retronasal -- slightly boozy, reminding of mildly rummy raisins or prunes when theyre quite young and juicy, not bitter hops but earthy, and ever present, and richly endowed with delicious and toasty malts.  Creamy and full mouthfeel is outstanding and carbonation seems perfectly done with only the slightest tingle at the back of the tongue, complimenting the wonderful finish of lingering pepper, mineral, and toasty barley.  This beer is good enough to bring new life into a style Id been bored with as of late.  Wish I bought more than two bottles.

Dark copper body with a small tan head.  Malty aroma with faint dark fruit and a mild hops.  Flavor: blend of malt and hops - slightly bitter, mild bread, a faintly peppery; dry aftertaste includes alcohol and bread.
On-tap at Dees. Like a smooth barleywine. Interesting and good. Tea light brown colour, nuts and malt, grapes,molasses, vanilla. roasted barley. Hop in aroma. Medium mouthfeel. Suitable carbonation.
minimal head and no lacing on this copper brew.  aroma of bread, hops, and fruit.  taste was sweet malt, alcohol, and hops.  maybe alts just arent my thing.

Sampled from bottle.  This alt pours cloudy bronze with a creamy, light-tan head and nice lacing.  Aroma is toasted malts with subtle notes of dark fruit.  Bready, carmelized malts with apples and plums.  Flavor lingers.  Full-bodied and smooth.  A bit under attenuated and a bit too fruity.  Quite good.

Now that weve concluded our 100th review, weve set out on our next journey as we head towards 500. It began with the Ten Years Alt from Victory Brewing. It pours a medium amber color with an average-sized, frothy light-brown head. Hardly any lacing, and the head diminishes down to almost nothing. Still body. Aromas are of moderate-strength light bread malts and light flowery hops. MB and HH picked up peach and vanilla, as well as mango. Initial flavor is moderately bitter, lightening to a sweet finish. Oily at first on the mouth, we were left feeling dry and chalky. Soft carbonation on the way down. Not our favorite from Victory, but they have yet to do us wrong.

Bottle shared with GregClow, Blankboy, Hogtown Harry, and Jerc, Pauls bottle.   Spicy aroma, slightly dark fruit - hard to explain, it was odd.  Copper, small off-white head.  Harsh alcohol taste.  Full of flavour, grainy.  But harsh!  It just doesnt go away or fade to reveal anything else.  I just got all alcohol, and thus, did not enjoy it that much at all.  Disappointing.

12 oz bottle.  Best by 8/10/06.  Metallic, funky methane-like aroma.  Kinda smells like ass.  There are some caramel sweet aromas as well, but unsettling.  Transparent garnet/copper color with a quickly dissipating small off-white head.  Virtually no lacing.  Sharp, boozy flavors with some sweetish maltiness present with a few bitter hops in the end.  Quite medicinal, and I think this is very poor.  This is NOT how to celebrate 10 years brewing.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow, jerc & tupalev -- courtesy of hopdog. Pours a clear orange-ruby with a good size diminishing off-white head. Aroma of -- whoa, thats weird! -- mat, spices, fruit of some kind, hops and... what is that? Odd. Flavour of sweet caramel malt, spices and alcohol -- its quite boozy. Medium bodied. Not bad but I personally did not care much for it.

Clear copper body. One or two mentionable bubbles slowly gliding up within. Smallish firm capping of dirtied tanned froth. Long, boney fingered lace spans across the glass.

Aroma is what Id call tall and slim. Lovely whole grain bready aroma thats fresh and reaching with a slight nutty dryness, a slim sweet fruityness and a dusting of chocolate.

Taste is well blended and balanced with malts bringing lightly dry bread tones floating off the middle from its sweetish start. From midway to the finish this is all unquitting flavors on the palate. Great bready grains and caramel with very adequately balanced floral hoppyness and dry leafyness. Finds time to squeeze in some fruits just before the swallow. Very intriguing and complex. Lengthy too. One of the higher qualities that I liked about it was that it lasted on the buds and begged for more as it did. Nice!

Feel is just a notch above medium. Fairly filling, yet smooth and succulant with a well rounded appeal thats quite quenchable. Mostly detained from the middle and into the finish where it almost seemed to gain more and more control and attention. Solid carbonation. The hops begin to find their home after a while. And there where and when they find it, which is sooner than later, its dry, grassy, floral, and nutty. Fantastic.

A wonderfully balanced beer with lots of flavor packed fun. It grows on ya might quick and is gone just as so. And 8.5%, please...where it is, is probably a couple more later when youve nearly drained em as fast as youve poured em.

Raise another flag in victory for Victory for this fabulous Anniversary Alt!

Bottle (12oz).  Shared with blankboy, GregClow, jerc and Tupalev - blankboys bottle.  Poured clear copper with a small diminishing off-white bubbly head.  Light sweet roasty malt aroma, light orange juice and bitter orange zest, sweet juicy floral hops.  Taste is initially roast malt, then sharp black pepper and yeast, then its almost overwhelmed by alcohol and dry hop bitterness - it finishes slowly and quite bitter.  Average body, okay level of astringency and carbonation - enjoyable,  really dry and bitter.

Brown body with a small tan head. Sweet malty aroma, something fruity and odd, touch of alcohol. Sweet caramel malt flavour is usurped by dry bitter finish. Average palate. Interesting but is not really doing much for me.

Bottle shared with blankboy, HogTownHarry & tupalev - courtesy of blankboy. Reddish-amber with a small head. Very nice, earthy/organic aroma - rich malt and resiny hops. Sweet, caramel flavour, with some interesting spicey notes and a long, dry, slightly boozy finish. Really nice.
Great deep reddish color but overall, a bit too malty for my tastes. There is a slight alcohol character, but not overpowering. O.K. - but not one of my favorite styles.

Sampled at 3Floyds Dark Lord Day. Nice foamy pour atop an appealing dark body. Guess Id just call it a good "dark beer" smell, malty rich, and free of distractions. Taste is light toasted malts, with caramel and just a bit of porter malts, all well balanced with strong German hops, a bit spicier than usual. Hints of smooth ale taste.
This is very nice....full and packed with different flavours....the alcohol is masked very well, 8.5 ..who flippin knew...nice colour, sweet smell...hops are big but controlable....alts r nice.

Fruity, sweet flavor with a nice hoppy profile.  This is a very good representation of an altbier, which can be hard to excel at.  Having trouble putting my finger on all the flavors that exist; there are a lot of things going on here.  Alcohol is relatively well hidden for 8.5%.

12oz. Bottle:  Picked up a sixer at the brewery.  This one pours a slightly hazy coppery color.  There wasnt much head, and what was there dropped off quickly.  The nose has hints of caramel and maybe some hops in there also.  Maybe a whiff of fruits also.  An interesting taste.  Slightly sweet and also peppery.  Maybe a touch of fruit and cinammon also.  Intersting and complex.  Too bad its a one of.  I could get used to this one.

Wonderful coper color with a nice head.  I usually do not like these older styles but this is great.  It has modest flavors but still retains that old world flavor.  A bit sweet with the 8.5% alcohol well hidden.

At first the aroma was simply grainey,eventually a little berry came through . Taste was a slightly sweet berry with spicy peppery hop taste,almost like there was a touch of cinnimon in there. That spiceness threw me, i prefer the Zum Uerige

The aroma is a slight citrus and a sweet dough. The head is fully diminshing with a little lacing. The color is a brown/orange and it is a good tasting ale.  The flavor is short but I just finished some habanero chips so this could be misleading. This is my second six-pack and is a good beer that I think most my friends would enjoy and some have.

This bottled brew sampled at Dicks Bodacious Bar-B-Que RB event poured a quickly diminishing head of no bubbles that left a body of transparent orange brown color with no carbonation.  The aroma was mild with soft malty notes.  The mouth feel was vinous from start to finish with a mild burn and an overpowering alcohol flavor.

This beer pours a deep amber with a small tan head leaving a little lacing down the sides.  Not much aroma, but what is there citrusy, kiknda hoppy?  very warm taste as previous tasted noted not one of victories better beers, but I do like it.  Cheers!
UPDATED: APR 26, 2006 Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours  amber with a small white head. Aroma of hops, citrus, caramel. Flavor is bitter, citrus, slight fruit , sweet.

Bottled.  Thanks to zathrus13 for the bottle.  Pours deep burgundy with an ivory head.  Aromatic nose with fruits, honey, malt and tobacco notes.  Sweet with a spicy note.  Rather bitter.  More tobacco notes .  Bitter finish.

Hazy, bronze appearance  with a small, off white head and modest lacing.  Nose was malty, earthy, and  a bit fruity with a hint of berries and tea.  Hops asserted themselves  the rest of the way, although the citrus angle was downplayed.  Well carbonated, medium bodied mouthfeel with a nicely balanced finish.

Pours a clear dark copper with a thin ring of light tan head.  Sweet toasty caramel malty aroma has a big hoppy presence for an alt.  Body starts with a lightly sweet earthy caramel maltiness turning more bitter, dry and alcoholic toward the finish.  Overly attenuated and needs more sweetness for the style.

Bottle. Stone smoked aroma, with some fruit. Amber body; no visible carbonation. Clear body; excellent lace. Strong initial mouthfeel from a considerable alcohol profile. Excellent Alt. Strong and dry. Almost harsh, almost cloying....roasted caramel malt. An excellent effort with a style that is underutilized and potentially underappreciated.

Bottle. Tasted better than it smelled.Tan head with minimal lacing, transparent, no visible carbonation, and an orange hue. Nose was hoppy, malty and sweaty socks. Flavor was malty, somewhat sweet and hoppy. Smooth palate and medium body.
Draught.  Brown-red appearance, with off-white head.  Very malty, caramel, sweet nose.  Flavor sam, good roasty finish.  Slightly dry at end, tad on the hoppy side.

12 oz bottle.  Amber/copper color, clear, medium head.  Nice resiny hop aroma with malt to back it up.  Okay it is pretty bitter but this is similar to Uerige Alt in Dusseldorf if you have had it.  Granted this is a stronger alt and there is also some alcohol to accompany, it is reminiscent of Uerige (the hoppiest Alt in Dusseldorf).  Nice malt and sweetness to balance the whole range of flavors.

Thanks to FrumptyDumpty for the hookup on a 12oz bottle. Poured a copper with an off-white head. Aroma was malts with a touch of bown sugar, spices and some hops hidden in there. Flavor followed with maltsand brown sugar with a good spicey touch. Finish seemed to be a tart grapefruit. A very good brew from Victory.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2007 From a 12oz Bottle.  Courtesy of slob.  Pour of cherry, oak, and honey, glazed with a light whipped topping of frothy head.  Refreshing hoppy aroma of mandarin orange peel, complimented by a sweet brown sugar and caramel maltiness.  Body is relatively thin, but the sugary sultriness from the nose comes through cleanly and pleasantly on the palate.  Immediately following is a crisp blue spruce bite of hops, giving it a rather pleasant tongue scrubbing finish.  Final smack has a bit of an alcoholic bite that resembles a dry gin martini.  Thanks, Bert!7-3-6-2-13=3.1From a 12oz Bottle. Expiration 8/2006.  Rated Blind.  Pours a mostly hazy, firey peach flesh color with a thin layer of wispy off-white head.  Lots of tropical fruit in the nose, including notes of pineapple and mango, glazed with some spiced rum and brown sugar.  Hints of coconut and toasted brazil nuts topped on a crispy wheat cake.  Some alcohol warmth noted, but not overly harsh.  Full bodied, lightly carbonated mouthfeel, softening up the body somewhat, but not contributing much character beyond that.  Slightly oxidized and papery, with a hint of woody cocounut husks.  A restrained caramel and strawberry malt flavor starts to come through, heavy and plodding, disguised by dry wood.  Some high alpha white grapefruit hops come out mid-palate, but they dont contribute much other than an intense bitterness that builds into the finish.  An oily, highly bitter, pithy red pine hop reside rests on the tongue in the final smack.

This beer is excellent.  Crisp hoppy edge balanced against the malt side with its light caramel notes.  Amber body with a medium size head.  Easier to drink when colder, but let it warm up and show you what its made of.  Cheers Victory.  Heres to ten more years!
From bottle thanks to Immy.  Pours a ruby red with tan head.  Nose is sweet malts with some light hops.  Flavor follows with some bitter in the finish.  Nothing too exciting.

Tap at brewpub.  Poured a crisp copper body with a frothy off-white head.  The aroma is sweet carmel and brown sugar.  Flavors were a somewhat spicy carmel malt with nuts and brown sugar with a piney/grassy finish.  A very good Alt.
Copper, off white head, malty aroma, flavor of caramel, some spice, earthy, with floral hops. Pretty good.

12 oz bottle. Copper pour with an off white head. Sweet, malty brown sugar nose, with some spices and floral hops peeking through. Medium bitter with a big malt backbone, spices really shine in the finish. Another winner from Downingtown!

Pours to a nice copper body with a thick beige head.  The aroma is vanilla cookies (Nila Waffers) and floral/perfumey hops.  The flavor is floral, soapy, perfumey, caramel, odd woodsy toastyness.  Also, a bitter pineyness s present.  The palate is bitter and medium bodied.  Un-necessarily bitter.

Bottled.. enjoy by 8/10/06.  Poured a rich, medium coppery-caramel with a couple inches of beige headage.  Very interesting nose... flowery notes meet lightly-toasted dark malts meet spices.  A lot in there, but a floral/woodsy aspect stuck out the most.  Flavor profile had a spicy and caramel malt backing, with bright woody and alcoholly sparkle all around the tongue.  Light-bodied, yet heavy feel on the palate, gaining thickness toward the back.  Finish was of dark fruits, caramel, earth, spices and alcohol.  Tasty and complex.

Bottle. Pours a deep amber minus much head.  Caramel and vanilla essences on the nose.  Mouthfeel is thick, fruit and a little hops with a sprinkle of sweet.  There was another flavor that alt-ered the taste of this brew which I could not put my finger on.  However, I did not mind it all.

Pours out brown with not very much head.  Taste is sweet, malty, and fruity.  Has a nice spicy hop flavor to it as well.  Certainly a good beer, though it is something that does have a slightly awkward flavor.  Not bad

12oz. bottle best by 8/02/06. Slightly hazy dark amber color with a medium sized beige head. Mild toasted malt aroma with an odd metallic scent and a hint of hops. Rich malty, fruity flavor with the hops being much more apparent than in the aroma. Strong alcoholic finish makes the hop bitterness really stand out. Good, but really not to my tastes. Thanks Cornboy for giving me a bottle so I didnt have to buy a sixer myself.

12oz.:Thick amber color, small head off-whIte, quickly diminishing.  Very malty aroma, very nutty like newcastle.  Hoppy acidic flavor, unbalanced.  Warming up the beer, the acidity goes away, more balanced.  Still a semi-sweet aftertaste.

This brew from victory has many similarities to storm king and old ho from last year when fresh.  Something in the hops is very distinctly "victory".  Its a well balanced beer, maybe a bit too much on the alcohol but aging it a few months will smooth it out.
Good, but not 10 year good if you can understand.

Pours a murky brown with nice head.  Smell is strangely of pineapple.  Interesting to see a cloudy brown beer.  Taste is very malty with also a heavy metallic flavor, like putting a penny in your mouth.  Pretty strange.  Alcohol comes out very slightly at the end.  Kind of thick like a barleywine with that same sweetness, but Im getting this metallic flavor as the dominant one.  Weird.

Interesting.  Pours a murky brown color that seems indecisive in its opacity.  Not actively carbonated, but taste features a crispness and snappy taste of bubbles.  Flavors of roasted hops (?) come through strongly and the finish is clean with a slight maltiness lingering on the palate.  I want to say this is very enjoyable, yet I cannot find a good reason.  I do hope this stuff is around for a while.

12oz bottle: Clear amber body with a small beige head.  The nose has some light fruits, sweet malt, caramel, mild hops.  The aroma is very mild and subtle overall.  Taste shows some spicy hops, caramel, malt covered in chewy caramel, chocolate, and pepper.  The malt flavors here are well done and complex - showing many degrees of caramel/chocolate/grains.  Finish has bit of cracked pepper, light alcohol, spice, and floral hops.  Medium bodied, medium carbonated.

Color is a golden brown.  Smell of bread, pine cones, rasins, hops and some spice.  Tastes like a spicy-hop beer with little or no alcohol taste.  Also dry and bitter-sweet at the end.  This beer is very good for a $1.99 single bottle Discount Liqours.  I cant beleve its 8.5% alcohol? I really cant taste the alcohol.   Great beer.

Tastes slighty like an Old Horizontal Light...if you legitimately call such a substantial beer light.  You can taste the alcohol.  Reddish amber with light carbonation, hoppy, but not bitter hops.  Very good, get it while you can.

Looks reddish-brown, not very carbonated.  Hoppy, but not to be confused with Stone IPA.  Tastes mostly of alcohol.  Not a starter-level beer, but more accessible than many others.  Id say try it while you still can.
This was my First Altbier.  Hops present and good.  Malt hangs on the palate.     Satisfying in its depth of flavors.  Need this in Ohio.

The aroma was a touch hoppy, but instead of a bitter hop, it was a nice floral hop.  The color was a purplish-red with not much of a head.  The flavor had some caramel to it.  It was pretty smooth, and the mouthfeel was lighter than I would have expected.  Quite a nice beer.

Much thanks to Dave for the freebie!  Has a decent malty and fruity aroma.  Nice hazy brown body, with a little beige head.  Flavor is quite pleasant, slightly sour and fruity.  Good body and carbonation.  Overall, I found this quite enjoyable.

Pours deep amber with a thick tan head.  Good head retention when served on tap.  Aroma had sweet malts, caramel, currant, raisin and various other fruits,  Sour and alcoholic taste with caramel, currant and raisin mixed in with a strong alcohol taste.  Mouthfeel was acidic but still quite full.  A bit watery for the strength yet still effective.  As it went down it became more drinkable.  Good stuff.
I found this ale to be very skunky in aroma and has a bitter taste with a lingering palate.  I wasnt sure about this amber color ale at first but I grew to like it with every sip.

Bottle, from Julios. Enjoy by Aug 10/06. No problem there. Ok nose sweet & sour. caramel, grapefruit, raisin. Clean reddish orange color, good head that faded quickly to a ring, then nothing. Little to no lacing. Bitter flavor. Like aroma. Grapefruit, tinny, apple, caramel. Medium body, creamy oily mouthfeel, bitter finish. I enjoyed this, though its the bitterest alt Ive had. If I had it blind I would have guessed an ipa. Good brew.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Sample at Indy tasting Dicks BBQ 3/31/06 - Aroma is sweet raisins, carmel, and hops.  Pours transparent brown with small head and little lacing.  Flavor matches aroma with a lot more malt and a bit of chocolate.  Palate is sticky and sweet.  Pretty tasty stuff.
promising aroma followed by a rather arguable palate.  muddy brown with small head.

Bottle.  Clear red amber body under a small white head.  Light crystal aroma with an apple fruit kick.  Big malt flavor - wheat bread with caramel and honey gooped on top tempered by a bitter bakers cocoa and wood finish.  Piney, bitter hops linger on the tongue after a swallow giving a nice contrast to the sweet start.  Good mouthfeel, too.

On tap, pours a mahogany color with a thin head. The aroma is very fruity and the taste is very malty with nuts, slight citrus, caramel, and fruits.  It is a pretty sweet beer that could be a little well balanced with the hops at teh end, but overall is very drinkable.

Dark copper color with a thin head.  Syrupy aroma with an assortment of mixed nuts and a grassy finish.  Oddly fruity taste with dry pear and apple standing out on top of a dry malt body with some slight roasts.  Almost some salt on the finish.

Some chocolately, cocoa-caramel in the flavor.  Very dry, and ashy, with a fairly high mineral content.  Well-rounded, slightly bitter finish due to a surprising dose of hops.  Something like hazelnuts too in the flavor.

Bottle.  Nice hazy amber color, sweet malty aroma with a touch of hoppiness.  Excellent and well-balanced flavor between malts and hops -- nothing is overpowering.  Smooth, mildly carbonated mouthfeel; perfect for this ale.  I grabbed this one at the store when I really needed something to cheer me up, and it definitely did the trick.  Another superb ale from Victory!

Bottle. Pours deep amber with a minimal-one finger thick white head. Aroma of hops, citrus, caramel. Flavor is bitter, citrusy, slight fruit notes, sweet upfront. Not bad, but not the best Victory beer.
Dark red with a small white head.  Pleasant malty aroma.  Smooth and delishous.  Not a hint of the alochol.  A very good beer, if not a normal alt.
This was a very dry beer but also pretty decent.  I had it on tap, so perhaps that differs somewhat from the bottle, but overall, nice appearance, aroma, and flavor.  Give it a try.

Bottle  Pours a muddy dark amber with a small light tan head.  The head is fizzy and deinishing.  Has a good malty aroma but seems well balanced with a nice touch of hops.  Has an alcoholic texture.  A little bit above light bodied.  Its very well carbinated.  Has a good duration.  This beer produces a nice finish.  Has a good bitter kick to it.  A good beer to celebrate Victorys ten years.

Tap at Waterfront Ale House, Brooklyn - Hazy light red in color - lots of fruity esters in the aroma, mostly strawberry, some citrus to compliment the moderate hoppiness - a little on the sweet side - lots of sticky, caramel malt sweetness and sugar-covered light fruits - hops are assertive, but still not enought to counterbalance the sweetness - some darker roasted malts and a smokiness come in near the end, making things a bit more interesting - I salute Victory for not going overboard for their anniversary ale, but that doesnt mean I have to like it very much.

Draught pint at Sunset Grill on 3/23/06Frothy, but small and mostly diminishing beige head atop a bright auburn-magenta-tinged copper-amber.  Light chill haze to it, with some minor lacing.Nose is surprisingly bursting with fruity hops.  Well, perhaps not bursting, but they are large, round and full of yellow fruit notes.  Plenty of ripe peaches, predominantly, with a light brassy-mineral note of alt yeast, deep toasted grains providing fair depth with no sign of alcohol.  Light poundcake sweetness is quickly curtailed by bitter, dry, tettnang-like soily/hay notes.  Of medium strength is the aroma.The flavor continues the hop trend, with bountiful bitterness wedded to lightly sugary pale malts, with a tastefully done toasted malt, vienna-like huskiness that seems to offset the juicy hops perfectly.  Very impressed with the abundance of hop flavors and bitterness without any suggestion of PNW.  Good for them.  Fairly nominal texture, with mostly tight carbonation, perhaps a little too expansive at times, but deep enough malts, peachy-fruits from the hops, hay, sweat and grass as well, and no sign of alcohol in the flavor.  Darkens, with more sign of the roasted malts, as it warms, but nothing to get worried about. Balances the drinkability of an alt with the added flavor and gravity of a sticke alt.

Bottle; Best by August 1, 2006:  Beer pours very attractive, slightly cloudy copper color with a thick, rich, totally retained beige colored head.  Aromas include rich sweet malt of the cereal, biscuit type and I suppose a bit of hops lurking in there under the malt.  The hops really shine through in the flavor with some sharp bitter citric notes which are very well complimented by the sweet rich malt and a bit caramel flavor.  Very enjoyable beer.  I am glad I bought a sixer.

(Bottle (enjoy by 8/10/06) from <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/massachusetts/w target=blank>Julios Liquors) Pours dark golden brown with a nice-looking biscuit head. Smells piney, hoppy, sour, honeyish, yeasty. Thick weepy lacing. Sharp hop bite upfront, then licorice and malt. Bitter finish and lingering bitter aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel although a touch watery.

12oz bottle. Pours a clear dark brown/amber color with a thick creamy light tan head. Head leaves thick sporatic lacing. Nose is lots of toffee, brown sugar, sweet malt, very nutty,floral hops, and caramel. It smells sticky like taffy. Body is a little thin at first but thickens up as it moves. Flavors start off as nutty and malty, but follow up with some off flavors. Some light weird, dirty water notes. A peppery touch that stings the tongue. A film is left on the palate and the tongue is staind.

Bottle courtesy of hopdog. Ruby brown pour with a small tanned head. Nose is spicy and hoppy with some herbal notes, semi-sweet malts aromas, caramel and light honey. Taste is heavy on the spice with more herbal notes, flowery hops, light toffee, and honey. The spice profile seems very pepper laden. Body is medium but has a fine carbonation feel and a certain smoothness/slickness to it. Finishes with a big spice and hop flavor. Light roasty malts, sort of coffee-ish, with light caramel, ground pepper, flowers, and herbal notes and light wood. Nice beer!

Beautiful pour to a translucent red-clay color with a creamy tan head quickly recessing to an icy, oily web on top with a creamy tan rung at the sides.  Beady vellum lacing slowly cascades down the glass as we go.  Aroma is ignited with cherry toffee, maple beachwood, copper accents, spicy peppery touches, amaretto coffee creamer and honey nectar.  Such a rare, unique display of aromatic affection.  Flavorful force pushes full stream ahead.  Hoppy sticke accents come to the forefront, dancing with a dry, clean, caramel and chocolate percussion.  Dry, woodsy balsa tendencies, sticking with a piney, cedar sap vibrancy.  Buttery pecans and pralines partner with expressive caramel ribbons.  Clean, dry and bitter, and then an unquenching, unflinching meld of the tongue to the top of the mouth is upon us.  Splices the inner mouths central domain in two.  Quite a hoppy alt creation, but a priceless introduction and foray by an American craft brewery into the world of alts.  Bitterness crests on the arc at the back of the throat in the finish, along with some cedar resin and peppered toffee cubes with a maple liquor heart.  You can take your 10 malts - 10 hops - 10% abv anniversary ales; Ill side with this testament to 10 masterful years of brewing at Victory any day of the week.  Huge thanks to bstill and Jhop for the bottles!

Poured a clear golden amber color with a thin off-white head.  Malty sweet aroma with toffee and fruits.  Mainly apple and pear.  The flavor had a malty start and a long dry big bitter finish.  Light to medium body

Beer poured with a head that didnt last long. Was a deep copper color but it had a slight chill haze present in the beer. As the beer warmed up some it was clear. Malt  aromas with some vegetable type aromas also. Heavy malt flavor with a an astringent type bitterness that follows. It did not seem like a clean hop bitterness to me. The finish was dry and not as pleasant as I expected. I do like the alt style very much. I have had and enjoyed the Zum Uriege Stick alt and the Stick and Jab from Heavyweight. I was dissapointed in this beer from Victory as I was expecting a better beer. I will need to try their version of a regualr alt as I have not had that one yet.

"Poured a dark copper color. head was fluffy and laced just okay. Aroma was malty and with some citrus. Flavor was roasted malts caramel chocolate and come citrus. Finished bitter. Overall good beer."
Hop aroma awoke me with a pleasant surprise.  The dry roastedness is a little flat, and doesnt hold up to the punch and kick of the hops.  lacking the mild sweeness that I expect in the style.

Clear and colorful umber color with a smaller beige head. Fairly clean aroma, with some light, fruit and flowers along with a scone or biscuit aroma.  Loads of caramel flavors in the front. The strength is quite evident. Light raisins and mild spice in the finish. Slightly warming in the linger.  Lightly oily, slightly sticky feel. A doppel sticke that is a bit to assertive at times.

Bottle. Dark honey body with a thick lasting film of dense bubbles. Nose-sweet malt with some PNW hops. Taste-bread dough, fruit esters, sharp CO2, alcohol on the exhale, unsweet chocolate, almonds, pecan shells. Very bready. Kind of reminds me of what a Rochefort 10 would taste like if you brewed it with half the ingredients. Not bad at all, and excellent interpretation of the style.

Bottle bought in Michigan and served in my GL snifter: Poured a deep sunset orange with a small fuffy head and some cling. The nose detects a grassy and floral hop character, biscuity and husky malt, moderate allspice and strangely lemongrass (?), and some estery vapors. The taste starts with a layer of sweet and bready malts on top the spiced and noble hops are found. The palate seems to detect a lot of veggie character, which made me back-off quickly, but that faded quickly and left a mild bitter and bready aftertaste that is the mark of a classic Alt. In the end, I enjoyed this more when it warmed to me. By far it is hardly a classic example of the genre but seemed to be better as a whole than many I have tried.
Draft at the Grey Lodge in Philly. Solid version of an alt. Tasted what it should be didnt knock my socks off.
Bottle at Railroad Blues, Alpine, TX  Pours a cloudy amber with nice lacing.  Aroma is a winey malt blend.  Flavor is a hoppy cotton candy blend.  Palate flows.  Good brew.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Bottle - A spicy, very aromatic beer.  Big malty and hoppy flavors wit a sweet finish.  An excellent beer witht he alcohol well hidden.
Intresting dark orange body waffs out notes of clove, correander, cinamon, and orange.  Flavour is a suprising blend some spicey malts and nice wet grassy hop aroma.

(many thanks to hopdog for this bonus brew)poured a dark orange body with a small off white head.aroma was a mx of earth,wheat,and a tiny bit of hops.flavor was a mix of the same with a bit of chocolate thrown in.as it warmed the hops stood out a bit more giving it a nice blance.solid brew for sure.

Solid beer, but nothing amazing.  Blindfolded i could mistake the opening taste for their Prima Pils, especially when it is very cold.  As it warms, the roasted malts come out more strongly.  Even at its peak, though, it still tastes like they took their pilsner recipe and added some roasted malts.  This would be an OK beer were it part of their standard line, but the 10th anniversary deserved something better...maybe an oak aged V12 or something to blow my hair back.

This is a nice blend of brews, and hides the midlly high alcohol well.  The aroma isnt that great, maybe a slight bitter hop. Taste is almost like a mix of a bitter and an IPA.  Has a nice roast beginning and then has a nice hop finish, almost a creamy texture to it, pretty nice brew overall.

To be honest I was expecting a top fermented version of St. Victorious, but I was mistaken. I found this beer to be very smooth and drinkable. It was amazing how well the alcohol was masked. Will we see an 11th anniversary beer?

Pours a deep orangish-amber with a tiny head that was gone after a couple of seconds.  Sweet but very weak aroma of oranges, citrus fruit, pine hops and spices.  Pretty good flavor however, with an excellent balance of spicy hops and caramel tasting malts.  There is a lingering spicy-bitter finish with a citrus sourness.  Has an oily texture with moderate carbonation level.  Overall, I wasnt impressed.  I was expecting another superb Victory beer, but what I got was only average at best.
I expected alot more from Victory.This is, without a doubt a very weak effort. I hope another 10 years pass, before I write anything harsh about Victory!

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2006 Re-rate. Had this one on tap after having tried it in the bottle. The draught version, suprisingly, was not as good. The flavors were all there, but there was a distinct metallic aroma and aftertaste that put me off a bit.

12 oz bottle. Clear amber-orange color with foamy off white head. Nutty, roasty caramel malt nose with occasional tobacco undertones. Spicy and roasty up front with some hop bitterness. Dry, roasty malt flavors. Lingering bitterness.

darkly stained mahogony colured with a soft head that unfortunatly was a bit thin. This head had great staying power as it faded into a coating over my beer, not just some lace. This beer is almost exactly as described, a bit of spice at first fading into a really wonderful sweet malt flavour with a finish of roasty hops. Ive got a dry and bitter aftertaste long after taking a sip. I just noticed it is listed at 8.5% and wouldnt have guessed it.

Bottle: Ruby caramel, large foamy off-white head, sticky lacing, very light carbonation.   Smooth maltiness to start, citrusy sweet, but there is this bitterness that does not attack the tongue.   Instead, it hangs out on the back part of the roof of your mouth.   This one is an odd duck.   Citrus rind is sweet to start, but towards the end it becomes more bitter.   Now finally the back of the tongue gets a tingly bitterness developing.   Big bodied, mouthfeel is fairly moderate.   Doesnt seem like a big Altbier to me, but instead a weird Amber + Hefty IPA concoction.   Decent, but subtlety is lost with the strong citrus bitterness that develops at the end.   However, it is still fairly enjoyable for what it is.   Thanks to both zathrus13 and hopdog for this one!

Nice clear dark honey body with a short lived beige head.  Nice grainy aroma with some apricot and light spicyness.  Taste had a slightly astringent grainyness balanced by ample malt sweetness.  Also has a spicy hop charachter with some fruityness and bitterness in the finish.  Mouthfeel was rich and coating, with a nice amount of CO2.  Wonderfully balanced, great beer.

Thanks to rater zathrus13 for the recent amazing trade! 

Rating # 935
Pours a dark bronze body and a downy tan hued head. The aroma is largely malty, multigrain cereal; a clue of maple syrup, and what ploys me to believe, a docile earthy hops. The flavor brings a nice helping of caramel, toffee, a refined nuttiness, hints of coco, plum, some raisins; all backed by a spicy somewhat herbal, bittering hoppynes; hints of pine resin, spruce chips, citrus oils, rosemary. A pretty damn hoppy Alt! All Finishes with a bittersweet conjunction of biscuity malts and raw citric hops finishes dry as a petrified log! Although a slight metallic suggestion lingers in somewhere???? 
 Overall A fine beer practically worthy of a 10 year milestone Victory celebration

Cloudy dark bronze with a medium, dense off-white head. Bready caramel and floral hops in the nose. Flavor is massive and malty. Big on the side of kilned malt/toastyness, caramel, toffee and wood. Next, comes a blast of spicy noble hop bitterness which works well in conjunction with the malty sweetness. Some alcohol detected in the finish. Medium body, smooth texture with moderate carbonation. Spiderweb lacework on the glass, decent head retention. Very good stuff.

(12oz bottle, best by 8/2/06) Small beige head atop a lightly hazed copper body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, cookie, caramel, some plum, light salt.  Taste is moderately sweet, sharp grassy/herbal, caramel, some cookie, grapefruit.  Smooth medium body, surprisingly light on the tongue, light acidity, alcohol well-hidden.  This is delicious, but much too bitter to be considered an Alt.

Draft at the brewpub. Pours reddish brown. Faint spicy hop aroma with some hints of dark dried fruits and caramel. Malt profile has hints of nuts, brown sugar,  and caramel all balance by the pleasant spiciness of the hops. Smooth but bitter finish. This definitely has some house characteristics, which is fine by me. Not the best example of the style, but still darn good.

"This is an inspired choice of style for a 10th anniversary beer. Three bottles yielded three different experiences, but all were enjoyable. Generally, this has a lot of malt fruitiness, actually reminds me of some abbey dubbels in this regard, but its cut through with an exquisite bitterness and dryness which gives it quite an edge. The bitterness really cant be overemphasized. This is one of those few beers that I like a lot, but wouldnt buy on a regular basis. So its perfect, then, that it is one-time offering."
Britt informed me of this being an alt, I figured I would never get to try it, then Doug tells me its in town and brings me three ... Copying Britts entire rating as last night after having two back to back (had one previous night) I was thinking the EXACT same in that I each bottle left me with a slightly different perspective. All in all I really enjoyed it, but felt rather odd that what amounts to a 36 oz. sample didnt manage to complete my vision of how I would sum this up ...

Thanks to JHop for this one!  12oz bottle, enjoy by 8/1/06.  Nice amber pour with a light head.  Malty, hoppy, nutty bitterness.  A bit floral.  Strange mix of solid malt body with a strong nutty-spicy hop presence.  Light metallic hints.  Very bitter finish.  Body starts creamy but ends with dry bitterness.  Some reason I kept thinking of a steam beer.  Not at all bad.  A good effort.

Thanks to argo0 for bringing me a bottle. Murky chestnut to rufous body topped by a small but dense manila head. The aroma  is quite nice, dark fruits, sweet caramel, even some toffee and lets not forget the noble hops. The flavor is really good. Good balance of sweetness and bitterness. The hops really shine to the point that this is a n extremely  hoppy alt. Roasted malts blossom as it warms. Full bodied with a big hop bitter finish. I really dig this one. Now to somehow find more...

12 oz. Bottle. Nice sweet malt and floral nose. Pours clear dark copper color with a thin white head and minimal lacing. Very aggressive hop bitterness and flavor with a good amount of sweet malt behind it. Right now I would say it is out of balance and too hoppy for style but I (nor should anybody) rate to style, so I think it is a tasty hoppy amber. Im sure it will get better with age judging from the alcohol(which is noticeable but not overwhelming). I will put back a few and see how it develops.

12oz bottle as a bonus brew from hopdog!  - Thanks Steve! - Pours dark copper with some haze and creamy tan head that settles back to a film but laces the glass from there down.  Aroma is a nice malty one.  Caramel, toasted malts,  a little yeast, and some spice.  Flavor is nice and malty as well, rich sweet caramel, roasted malts, cherry, yeast, spice, and some bitter hops on the finish blend with the warmth of the alcohol.  Palate is smooth and full bodied with much character and a somewhat dry finish.  A nice choice for an anniversary beer..  Enjoyable!

Pours a brilliantly clear, deep, dark, reddish color that shows ruby notes when held up the  light.  The head is initially one-finger thick, through it quickly disappears and is a light tan color.  The aroma is fruity with a bit of sweet candied cherry note to it.  There is also a light herbal and spice type note here as well as a light toasted malt note, which combines with a sweet caramel malt note.

The beer is full and coating up front, yet is not as sweet as I would expect from a beer of this heft.  An immediate, herbal, almost raw hop note is noticeable up front and continues on into a mouth gripping, solid bitterness.  I was expecting this to have an aggressive hop character like the best Alts I have had, which it does, but I was hoping for that intense, smooth fruitiness as well, which is not in this beer.  The hops, especially the herbal notes, seem to combine with some alcohols and perhaps some fusels to give this a bit of a harsh note towards the end.  This is pretty tasty, I just wish it were a bit less herbal and aggressive and a bit more balanced.  I have a feeling though, that this will mellow and become a much more rounded and balanced mix of flavors once it gets a couple months more of age.  Or perhaps it is just that I am haunted by the wonderful memories of tasting fresh Ale in Düsseldorf.

This is an inspired choice of style for a 10th anniversary beer.  Three bottles yielded three different experiences, but all were enjoyable.  Generally, this has a lot of malt fruitiness, actually reminds me of some abbey dubbels in this regard, but its cut through with an exquisite bitterness and dryness which gives it quite an edge.  The bitterness really cant be overemphasized.  This is one of those few beers that I like a lot, but wouldnt buy on a regular basis.  So its perfect, then, that it is one-time offering.

Deeply hazed coppery crimson, creamy light tan head.  Subdued nose of toffee, citrus, earth, grass, and softer tones of chocolate.  Flavor is very well balanced. Toasted caramel malt and moderate underlying grassy citrus tones work well together.  Medium bodied, medium carbonation, very dry, bittersweet finish.  Good, but I really was expecting more...

Goofy sour/bitter taste.Looks and smells good.Aug 10,06 exp.Dosnt hold a candle to Uerige doppelsticke.Same alc/vol.Im sure after another 144 years
Victory will get the hang of it.Schells
2005 Snowstorm Alt was better at
1/2 the price.

Nice dry roasted malt aroma. A bit of caramel, sweet toffee. Neutral fruity hops and just a bit of diacetyl. Crisp and clean on, with just a bit of carbonic gaseousness. Dark amber brown clear with a thin off-white head. Medium bodied with medium-high carbonation. Starts with nice malt sweetness, caramel and toffee. Dry roasted, toasted grains. Really nice bitterness from start to finish. Good dryness and carbonic tang. A bit sweeter and more hoppy than altbiers Ive experienced in Germany, but quite good. Decent level of alcohol and sweet after. Flavorful, enjoyable altbier.

12 oz. brown, longneck bottle. Freshness date is of Aug 02, 06. Six pack was $9.99 + tax at my local watering hole. Poured out a deep mahogany color, with a thin off-white head. It leaft some nice lacing effects down the side of the glass. Aromas are of rich malts, with some slight citrus notes in the background. Flavors are of smooth lager yeast, fresh baked bread, malts, and earthy hops. Mouthfeel is rich & think. Alcohol is well hidden in this beer. No burning or hot flavors at all. A really decent attempt on the style.

Grapevine Market $10.29 six pack. Drank from coffee cups while sitting in front of Zingers hardware. Dark with thin head. Low carbonation kept the aromas faint. The flavor is all malty goodness. Roasty toasty whole grain honesty. No lingering floral or spice-cabinet imaginations. Alcohol is up front. Solid beer. Overpriced.

Nearly clear and dull red with little head. Floral hop and toasted malt aroma with rich caramel malt, some raisen a bit of roasted malt and a hint of cooked vegetables. Sweet and malty. Finishes fast and bitter. Very hoppy and bitter for the style. Nice overall flavors but quite unbalanced. I will have to try another bottle.

Bottle.  Enjoy by:  08/02/06.  A hazy amber pour with a small, bubbly British khaki head.  A nicely balanced aroma that features spicy hops along with a good bit of caramel and roasty maltiness.  Lots of toffee, wheat bread and some cinnamon.  The flavor is equally well-balanced.  Smooth and medium-bodied.  Caramel and toffee start things off and some bitter, though not very citrusy, hops finish things.  Seems like something that would be great for the fall season.  Spiciness pervades throughout.  Slight alcohol warmth at the end.  A sticky, bitterness in the finish that lingers.  I really like this.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2008 This is a very interesting and complex beer. Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a dark caramel color with a large tan head. The aroma is bready with an element of ripe fruit and a complex spicy undertone. The flavor is bready, yeasty and spicy with some caramel and pepper. There is a bit of an alcohol burn. The body is moderately thick and smooth.

Bottle... Clear, copper ale with a small, fizzy, khaki head. Caramel, citrus fruit, toffee and sweat in the nose. The flavor leans toward the bitter/hoppy side of balance with plenty of medium-dark, rich malts with notes of caramel, light, maple syrup and golden raisins. Full-bodied and lightly creamy with lively carbonation. Finishes with a blast of bittter, pink grapefruit rind prior to completely drying out.

I love altbier, I wish more breweries experimented with this style.  Pours up a dark brown, with a large frothy head.  Aroma is fantastic, lots of spicy hops.  Kind of thin mouthfeel, although the flavor is great, a little interesting, but still very very good.

Bottle.  Autumnal spices. apple ferment.  malty note, some fruity citrus-bitter hops.  good blance.  pours brown-flat. flavorful enough stuff. doesnt impress me as a top-shelf beer.  missing richness, but a good medium flavor and body beer.

from the bottle. poured cloudy amber with a very small off white head and no lacing. aroma, brown sugar pops out first, than malts, citrus. flavor some hops,  bitter, dry, as it warmed alcohol. this was a strange beer for me, since I got a sixer I will try again

bottle. pours a dark copper body with a small off-white head. great aroma of sweet cookies, soft toast, and herbal hops. assertive flavourful hops up front and shortly after there are sweet bread earthy malts. this is surprisingly very tasty. its hard to believe that there is 8.5% behind this medium body. bought at The Beer Depot in Ann Arbor.

Draft at Capital Ale House.  Medium orange amber, OK head.  Aroma of light caramel.  Full amber malt flavors, pleasant albeit undefined hoppiness.  Perhaps spicy.  Very enjoyable, highly drinkable beer.  I really liked this one, somewhat annoyed that I cant come up with any useful descriptors.

Thanks FrumptyDumpty. Nose of slight malts and hops. Nice medium-dark copper almost red color with a large head fading to about 2 fingers of tannish red head. Smooth and malty, quick bite of hops followed by oak and iron. Warm silky mouthfeel.

Dark rufous. Sticky and lathery ivory foam. Aromatically clean and airy with notes of dates, straw, jellied malts, grass, and fennel. Lightly toasty and richly earthy. Spicy whiff of alcohol and fruitiness. Lush, fluffy carbonation. Opens thoroughly rich with soft malt flavors, yet with an off medicinal astringency coupled with some harshly earthy malt derivatives. Assertively grassy hops arouse the senses with a sassy bitterness while a flurry of alcoholic warmth clams the soul. Dense pockets of juicy resins are sandwiched within the predominantly herbal hop character, but manage to withstand the substantially arid body. Malts become less rigid and much more refined as things progress, gaining a supple toffee sweetness kissed lightly with starfruit. Steadily firm on into the finish, as woody malts mesh effortlessly to create a harmoniously dry fusion of alcohol and anise. Alcohol is a bit too forward in both flavor and aroma and theres some unpleasant medicinal astringency, early on. Needs some (more?) Pilsner malt depth to soften things. Thanks, FrumptyDumpty.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Pours dark amber with a thin off-white head. The aroma is grassy hops and toffee. Flavor is mostly sweet, mildly bitter finish. Mouthfeel is chewy.

Bottle, two about 10 days apart.  Aroma was a little hoppy with a trace a grape.  Poured an almost burgandy brown with a nice head.  Flavor was caramel and grass, toast malts and grape.  Palate was decent pretty crisp.  Overall Id say this was good, not a real standout but good enough for a few at a time, alcohol is well hidden.  It seems this may be better ageing a little while because the initial bottle was way to hopped for the style.

12 oz bottle pours a copper rust color with very little head. Aromas of coriander, violets, and a hint caramel. There are soft flavors of grape candy, structured malt, and a nice crisp bitter finish. Victory really shows its strength in its German brews and this is another success. Very nice medium weight Alt.
Amber color with a thin reamy white head. Dark malt aroma with some hints of smoke. Sweet flavor with hints of caramel.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2006 i dont know how this is rated a 3.75, let alone anything near a 3....orangish brown body with medium white head and is very flat looking...aroma is very earthy and grainy; flavor is everything the aroma offers and nothing else (maybe add a pich of chalk or cardboard)...this is pretty much a drainpour, especially from a brewery like victory
Great red body with a white head. Very minimal aroma, some cheese, caramel and malts.  Good hops in the flavor, light fruits; pear, apple, maybe some bannana.  Tangy ending.

Dark amber body, medium off-white head.  Cerealy, grassy aroma, toast, and caramel.  Toasty body with light caramels and delicate sweetness giving way to harsh, astringent, bitter hops that last through the finish.  The end result was like chewing on the backyard leaf pile after it burns and smolders awhile.  Almost medicinal in quality.  Im going against the grain here, but this was not enjoyable.

(bottle - 12 oz) Clear copperish pour with a medium white head that lasts for a while. Aroma is a mix of a gentle hint of boiled vegetables, sweet malts and a touch of hops. Kind of smokey. The flavor is very malty at the start with some hints of smoke, dark fruits and lots of malt all throughout with a slight touch of hops at the end. Very smooth and sweet with a lot of alcohol as it warms up.

Pours an awesome color - clear dark amber - with a small off-white head.  Roasted caramel malt aroma.  Flavor has a nice complexity to it; tatses of caramel malts, smoke, dark fruit, and a little bit of chocolate.  I would never have guessed the alcohol content was so high; its extremely well-hidden.  Ive had very few altbiers in my life, but this is excellent.

Pours a nice clear dark amber color with a medium amount of offwhite manilla head.  Aroma is very malty and sweet with caramel notes and a distinct german hop prescence though I cant tell which one.  Flavor starts very sweet then immediately becomes very hoppy and abrasive, then finishes sweet and caramely.  Overall, a very very interesting and different beers.  Heres to many more years of great victory brews.

Thanks to Zathrus13 for this one. Had a sweet malty grain flavor,not much in the line on hops but more wheat-like. Very qauffable. Sweetened as it warmed and left a funky earthy flavor on the tongue. Enjoyed with 2 non-ratebeerians and both thought very highly of this. Thanks Jeff.

I expected Ten Years Alt to come is a fancy foiled top corked bomber.    But alas, it was bottled in a regular twelve ounce NR bottle.     Enjoyable mix of hops, caramel malts and spicy yeast.     Victorys German style brewing roots shine through in this Alt.

This is my first alt...pours a caramel cream/orange with a nice tan creamy head.  Smell is interesting...sweet malt, spice, and a bit of fruit.  Wow...taste is very good and full.  Carmel, bitter hops, warm sweet malt, lots of spice.  Mouthfeel is a bit heavy and way creamy as well.  I have to have some other alts to compare with, but Id say its a damn good beer from victory as usual...though perhaps not exciting enough to be a 10th anniversary.

Beautiful deep brown color - very slight haze and a bubbly head.  Aroma of citrus fruit, caramel, and a hint of mint.  well balanced and flavorful with stong malts, citrus, prunes, and some spice.  Finishes strong and dry.  Very nice offering.

Wow ... isnt this fun.  Let the artists at Victory loose with a Germanic style and an American touch.  European hops slammed to just the right side of over the top, wonderful spice, bitterness, and floral aromas.  Clear copper, almost Vienna roast color, with a nutty smokey taste.  Would age help?  Of course ... but who wants to wait?  I got mine so new that it had not been labelled yet on the bottling line.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2006 Pours a light orangish amber with a fully receding tan head. Aroma of roasty caramel, oak, and aromatic malt. Taste is sweet and malty with fragrant hoppy notes. Hints of toffee, citrus, and stinging alcohol. Mouthfeel is medium bodied and a bit resinous from all the hops. I found this beer interesting, but not all that impressive due to some rather harsh flavors. It still needs a bit longer.
textbook alt color, a deep copper.  clean yeasty and german/european hops aroma, with some nice woody malt as well. 8.5% is non-existent....an impressive beer, i hope to revisit!

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2006 Copper/amber color, with a light tan head. Aromas are fruit, malt, hops, and a touch of spice. Flavors are malt, hops, fruit, nuts, and spice. A bit bitter towards the end, and more hoppy than I thought it would be. Itd rather good now, but aging may take the edge off of the bitterness.

Deep copper colored with ruby hints, this one has a medium off-white head.  The aroma was fruity and caramel malty, with some hops and nuts.  The flavor is malty, nutty, and fruity, with a big hop presence.  Probably the hoppiest alt Ive had.  This one remains balanced and interesting as it warms up.  I bought a sixer to go, and just might go back for a jeroboam.

Congratulations to Victory for reaching the 10 year mark. This one pours a medium brown color with a white head. Malty aroma with notes of toffee and caramel. What would be a perfectly nice malty german style beer is sort of messed up with a strangely bitter finish. A decent effort but not exactly this best beer ever.

Pours a medium amber, mostly clear, and a thin white head that fades.  Aroma isnt nearly as powerful as I thought it would be compared to uerige.   Good amount of munich malts but not powerful enough somehow.  The flavor was nice and malty, a bit too light and crisp, but had a nice hoppiness in the end and a good bitterness.  Body was a bit too weak especially compared to uerige doppelsticke.
Malty. Slightly sweet. Almost barley wine style. Not yet there. But another quality brew from Victory.

On tap at the Victory 10 Year Anniversary party.  Pours a reddish, brown slightly hazy amber with an average tan lacing head.  Aroma of roasty caramel malts, dark fruits, smoke, light alcohol and bread.  Flavors of the same with a light hop bitterness.

On tap at Victory. Poured a deep brownish color with a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of caramel, fruity, light alcohol, roasted malts and light spices. Tastes of caramel, raisins, fruity and spices. Light alcohol finish.

Pours a clear, dark copper/orange. Light copper head of tiny bubbles diminishes quickly. Lots of dense, sticky lacing. Aromas of caramel, light fruit, honey, spices and alcohol. Flavor of fruits, malt, caramel followed by moderate hops and spice. This is a very well balanced brew. Mouthfeel is moderately creamy and slightly oily with moderate carbonation. Just an outstanding beer and an impressive domestic example of the style.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2006 [Gravity Oak Cask] Poured a dark amber / chestnut color with a medium sized, light tan head.  Aroma of caramel malt, citrus fruits, toffee, light spices, and some alcohol as well.  Taste of roasted malt, caramel, light chocolate, some citrus fruits, vanilla, light smoke, and a medium bitterness in the finish.  Creamy mouthfeel.

Outstanding domestic example of sticke bier, which is a brawnier version of Dusseldorf altbier. 10 years of Victory, and a wonderful beer to celebrate that milstone with. Its hard to find a good example of alt, let alone sticke outside of Dusseldorf, but Im happy to say Victory has got this one right. Ten Years Alt pours to a beautiful, bright, deep copper color, with a thick, white head that fades, and a moderate amount of carbonation. The nose is excellent with snappy and zesty herbal hop aroma, that leads into a slighty slick, nutty/sweet malty and fruity palate. This beer is very polished, round, and smooth on the tongue. Ten Years Alt finishes with more good smooth malt and fruit up front, then ends with a snappy burst of herbal/grassy hop bittereness that lingers. Stylistically, a very accurate example of sticke, and this beer joins the ranks of the few impressive, domestic examples of the style. Great beer, well worth seeking out.

Pours a very clear amber, with a fizzy tan head that fizzles out fast. Nose is faint and malty with subtle hop notes. Flavor is rich and malty, but not too sweet. A nice dry finish with some bitterness.
